北方的奥德赛: 作者：杰克·伦敦
An Odyssey of the North: by Jack London

北方的奥德赛: 雪橇和着挽具嘎吱嘎吱的声响和带头狗的脖子上发出的叮呤当啷的铃声，正在吟唱着永恒的哀歌；但是人和狗都累了，都不出声。路上铺着厚厚的、刚刚落下的雪。他们来自远方，雪橇上载着很多四开的冻得跟燧石一样僵硬的鹿。橇板紧贴着还没轧结实的道路，总是往后退，像人一样倔强。夜幕正在降临，但是这一晚他们没有帐篷可搭。雪从毫无生气的空中轻轻飘落，不是雪花，而是小巧精致的雪晶。天很暖和——只有零下十度——大家都不在乎。迈耶斯和贝斯特已经把护耳翻了起来，马尔穆特·基德连手套都摘下来了。
An Odyssey of the North: The sleds were singing their eternal lament to the creaking of the harnesses and the tinkling bells of the leaders; but the men and dogs were tired and made no sound.The trail was heavy with new-fallen snow, and they had come far, and the runners, burdened with flint-like quarters of frozen moose, clung tenaciously to the unpacked surface and held back with a stubbornness almost human.Darkness was coming on, but there was no camp to pitch that night.The snow fell gently through the pulseless air, not in flakes, but in tiny frost crystals of delicate design.It was very warm,—barely ten below zero,—and the men did not mind.Meyers and Bettles had raised their ear-flaps, while Malemute Kid had even taken off his mittens.

北方的奥德赛: 这群狗在下午的早些时候就已经累坏了，但是现在，它们开始展现出新的活力。那些感觉比较敏锐的已经有点儿坐立不安了——似乎无法承受拖索的束缚，想快点儿跑又犹豫不决，它们竖着耳朵，用鼻子吸着气。慢慢地，它们开始对那些感觉不灵敏的伙伴发火了，不断狡猾地咬着它们的后腿，催着它们前进。那些遭到责怪的狗也感染了这样的毛病，又将这样的毛病传给别的狗。最后，最前面那架雪橇的带头狗心满意足地高声吠了一声，匍匐在雪中，使出浑身力气绷紧了颈圈，往前冲去。别的狗都跟着它做。后面的皮带一缩，拖索一紧，一架架雪橇就冲向前方了。人们不得不抓紧橇把，猛地抬高双脚，以免被橇板压住。一天的劳累都消失了，他们大声喊叫着，催促狗快点儿前进。那群狗也用高兴的叫声回应着他们。它们在渐渐变黑的夜色中，放开脚步，啪嗒啪嗒地快速奔跑起来。
An Odyssey of the North: The dogs had been fagged out early in the afternoon, but they now began to show new vigor.Among the more astute there was a certain restlessness,—an impatience at the restraint of the traces, an indecisive quickness of movement, a sniffing of snouts and pricking of ears.These became incensed at their more phlegmatic brothers, urging them on with numerous sly nips on their hinder-quarters.Those, thus chidden, also contracted and helped spread the contagion.At last, the leader of the foremost sled uttered a sharp whine of satisfaction, crouching lower in the snow and throwing himself against the collar.The rest followed suit.There was an ingathering of back-bands, a tightening of traces; the sleds leaped forward, and the men clung to the gee-poles, violently accelerating the uplift of their feet that they might escape going under the runners.The weariness of the day fell from them, and they whooped encouragement to the dogs.The animals responded with joyous yelps.They were swinging through the gathering darkness at a rattling gallop.

北方的奥德赛: “往右拐！往右拐！”他们顺次喊道，一架架雪橇忽然偏离了主道，掀起一侧的橇板，像顺风行驶的小帆船一样向前奔去。
An Odyssey of the North: “Gee!Gee!” the men cried, each in turn, as their sleds abruptly left the main-trail, heeling over on single runners like luggers on the wind.

北方的奥德赛: 雪橇一下子冲了一百码，来到一个透着光亮的羊皮纸窗户前。一瞧就知道这座木屋是他们的家，里面有烧得呼啦响的育空式火炉和冒着热气的茶壶。但是这木屋已经被占领了。六十只爱斯基摩狗威风凛凛地一起咆哮着，这群浑身是毛的家伙猛地朝拉着第一架雪橇的狗扑了过去。门猛地开了，一个身穿西北警察的红色束腰制服的人，踏着及膝深的雪，沉着而公正地拿狗鞭的柄把那群疯狂的家伙收拾得老老实实。之后，双方握手，就这样，马尔穆特·基德被一个外人迎进了本属于他的木屋。
An Odyssey of the North: Then came a hundred yards’ dash to the lighted parchment window, which told its own story of the home cabin, the roaring Yukon stove, and the steaming pots of tea.But the home cabin had been invaded.Three-score huskies chorused defiance, and as many furry forms precipitated themselves upon the dogs which drew the first sled.The door was flung open, and a man, clad in the scarlet tunic of the Northwest Police, waded knee-deep among the furious brutes, calmly and impartially dispensing soothing justice with the butt end of a dog-whip.After that, the men shook hands; and in this wise was Malemute Kid welcomed to his own cabin by a stranger.

北方的奥德赛: 应该是斯坦利·普林斯去迎接他的，前面提过的育空式火炉和冒着热气的茶壶正是由他负责照看的。不过他正忙着接待客人。这些客人差不多有十来个，尽管都是为英国女王执行法规和传送信件的人，但我们却很难把他们归为某一类。他们有着不同的血统，但是同样的生活使他们成了同一种类型的人——身材瘦长却结实。他们有着硬实的肌肉、被太阳晒得黝黑的脸和平静的灵魂，因此他们总是目光明亮且坚定地注视着前方。他们驾着女王的狗，让她的对手闻风丧胆；他们吃的是她分发的很少的口粮，但是很快乐。他们见多识广，做过很多大事，他们的生活像一部传奇，但是他们自己却对此一无所知。
An Odyssey of the North: Stanley Prince, who should have welcomed him, and who was responsible for the Yukon stove and hot tea aforementioned, was busy with his guests.There were a dozen or so of them, as nondescript a crowd as ever served the Queen in the enforcement of her laws or the delivery of her mails.They were of many breeds, but their common life had formed of them a certain type,—a lean and wiry type, with trail-hardened muscles, and sun-browned faces, and untroubled souls which gazed frankly forth, clear-eyed and steady.They drove the dogs of the Queen, wrought fear in the hearts of her enemies, ate of her meagre fare, and were happy.They had seen life, and done deeds, and lived romances; but they did not know it.

北方的奥德赛: 而且他们过得非常舒适。其中有两个人伸开手脚大躺在马尔穆特·基德的床上，嘴里唱着歌，当初他们的法国人祖先到西北地区和印第安女人结婚时唱的就是这样的歌。贝特尔斯的床铺也被霸占了，三四个健壮的押运员裹着毯子，一边揉脚，一边听一个人讲故事。这个人在沃尔斯利进攻喀土穆的时候，在他的舰队中服过役。等他讲累了，一个牛仔就说起了当年他和布法洛·比尔游览欧洲各国首都时，所见过的宫廷、国王和王公贵妇。屋子的一个角落里有两个混血儿，他们是一起吃过败仗的老伙计，正在一边修理雪橇上的挽具，一边说着当时西北地区人们不断地起义，路易·里尔称王时的情形。
An Odyssey of the North: And they were very much at home.Two of them were sprawled upon Malemute Kid’s bunk, singing chansons which their French forbears sang in the days when first they entered the Northwest-land and mated with its Indian women.Bettles’ bunk had suffered a similar invasion, and three or four lusty voyageurs worked their toes among its blankets as they listened to the tale of one who had served on the boat brigade with Wolseley when he fought his way to Khartoum.And when he tired, a cowboy told of courts and kings and lords and ladies he had seen when Buffalo Bill toured the capitals of Europe.In a corner, two half-breeds, ancient comrades in a lost campaign, mended harnesses and talked of the days when the Northwest flamed with insurrection and Louis Reil was king.

北方的奥德赛: 粗鲁的笑话和更粗鲁的玩笑话此起彼伏，水路和陆路上相当危险的事从他们嘴里说出来，都变得很平常，似乎他们之所以会想到这些事情，只是因为其中一些滑稽可笑的情节。这些无冕英雄的话语深深吸引了普林斯，他们亲眼目睹了历史是怎样创造的，然而他们却把那些伟大的、带着传奇色彩的事情看作平日里一些普通的、偶然的小事情。他把自己宝贵的烟草毫不吝惜地分给大家；为了回报他的慷慨，已经生锈的记忆的链条展开了，淡忘已久的奥德赛式的故事也重新被想起来了。
An Odyssey of the North: Rough jests and rougher jokes went up and down, and great hazards by trail and river were spoken of in the light of commonplaces, only to be recalled by virtue of some grain of humor or ludicrous happening.Prince was led away by these uncrowned heroes who had seen history made, who regarded the great and the romantic as but the ordinary and the incidental in the routine of life.He passed his precious tobacco among them with lavish disregard, and rusty chains of reminiscence were loosened, and forgotten odysseys resurrected for his especial benefit.

北方的奥德赛: 交谈停止以后，客人们装上最后一袋烟草，解开他们裹得紧紧的皮毯子时，普林斯扭过头，准备跟他的老伙计进一步了解这些人的情况。
An Odyssey of the North: When conversation dropped and the travelers filled the last pipes and unlashed their tight-rolled sleeping-furs, Prince fell back upon his comrade for further information.

北方的奥德赛: “那好吧，那个牛仔的身份你是知道的，”马尔穆特·基德一边回答，一边着手解开他那双软帮皮鞋的鞋带，“那个跟他睡在一起、有英国血统的人，他的身份也很容易猜得到。至于其他的人，他们都是森林里的流浪汉，他们的血统太复杂，只有天知道。睡在门口的那两个人，是地道的‘法裔’，也就是‘木炭’。那个围着毛线围巾的小伙子——注意一下他的眉毛和下巴——你就会知道，曾经有个苏格兰男人在他母亲那个烟雾弥漫的帐篷里抹过眼泪。还有那个把斗篷枕在头底下的英俊年轻人，他有一半的法国血统——你听见过他说的话；他讨厌那两个睡在他旁边的印第安人。你知道吗，当年那些‘法裔’在里尔的带领下起义的时候，地道的印第安人却没有支持他们，从那以后，他们相互之间就没有什么好感了。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Well, you know what the cowboy is,” Malemute Kid answered, beginning to unlace his moccasins; “and it’s not hard to guess the British blood in his bed-partner.As for the rest, they’re all children of the coureurs du bois, mingled with God knows how many other bloods.The two turning in by the door are the regulation ‘breeds’ or bois brules.That lad with the worsted breech scarf—notice his eyebrows and the turn of his jaw—shows a Scotchman wept in his mother’s smoky tepee.And that handsome-looking fellow putting the capote under his head is a French half-breed,—you heard him talking; he doesn’t like the two Indians turning in next to him.You see, when the ‘breeds’ rose under Reil the full-bloods kept the peace, and they’ve not lost much love for one another since.”

北方的奥德赛: “但是，火炉边上那个阴沉着脸的家伙又是一个怎样的人呢？我打赌他肯定不会说英语。他一晚上都没开口说过话。”
An Odyssey of the North: “But I say, what’s that glum-looking fellow by the stove?  I’ll swear he can’t talk English.He hasn’t opened his mouth all night.”

北方的奥德赛: “你错了。他的英语很棒。你留意到他听人讲话时的目光了吗？我留意到了。但是他跟其他人并不沾亲带故。当他们说自己家乡话的时候，你就能看出他根本听不懂。我也在想他究竟是什么人。咱们来打探一下。”
An Odyssey of the North: “You’re wrong.He knows English well enough.Did you follow his eyes when he listened?I did.But he’s neither kith nor kin to the others.When they talked their own patois you could see he didn’t understand.I ’ve been wondering myself what he is.Let’s find out.”

北方的奥德赛: “往火炉里添些柴！”马尔穆特·基德瞧着那个身份不明的人，提高了嗓门吩咐他。
An Odyssey of the North: “Fire a couple of sticks into the stove!”Malemute Kid commanded, raising his voice and looking squarely at the man in question.

北方的奥德赛: 他立刻照做了。
An Odyssey of the North: He obeyed at once.

北方的奥德赛: “他一定是在什么地方受过训练。”普林斯低声评论道。马尔穆特·基德点了点头，然后脱下袜子，从躺着的人群里小心翼翼地走到火炉旁边。他把湿了的鞋袜和二十来双鞋袜挂在一起。
An Odyssey of the North: “Had discipline knocked into him somewhere,” Prince commented in a low tone.Malemute Kid nodded, took off his socks, and picked his way among the recumbent men to the stove.There he hung his damp footgear among a score or so of mates.

北方的奥德赛: “你觉得什么时候可以到达道森呢？”他试探着问道。
An Odyssey of the North: “When do you expect to get to Dawson?” he asked tentatively.

北方的奥德赛: 那个人细细将他端详一番之后才回答：“听说还有七十五英里。对吗？估计得两天吧。”
An Odyssey of the North: The man studied him a moment before replying.“They say seventy-five mile.So?Maybe two days.”

北方的奥德赛: 可以听得出他的口音有点儿特别，但是没有停顿，也没有琢磨用词。
An Odyssey of the North: The very slightest accent was perceptible, while there was no awkward hesitancy or groping for words.

北方的奥德赛: “过去来过这里？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Been in the country before?”

北方的奥德赛: “没来过。”
An Odyssey of the North: “No.”

北方的奥德赛: “西北地区呢？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Northwest Territory?”

北方的奥德赛: “去过。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Yes.”

北方的奥德赛: “在那里出生的吧？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Born there?”

北方的奥德赛: “不是。”
An Odyssey of the North: “No.”

北方的奥德赛: “那么，你到底从哪里来的呢？你和他们不是一个地方的人。”马尔穆特·基德把手朝那些赶狗的人一挥，就连在普林斯床上睡觉的那两名警察也包括在内。“你是从什么地方来的呢？我以前见过你这样的脸孔，尽管我不记得是在什么地方见过的了。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Well, where the devil were you born?You ’re none of these.”Malemute Kid swept his hand over the dog-drivers, even including the two policemen who had turned into Prince’s bunk.“Where did you come from?I’ve seen faces like yours before, though I can’t remember just where.”

北方的奥德赛: “我认得你。”他说了句不相干的话，立刻把马尔穆特·基德引到了另一个话题上。
An Odyssey of the North: “I know you,” he irrelevantly replied, at once turning the drift of Malemute Kid’s questions.

北方的奥德赛: “在什么地方？你见过我？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Where?Ever see me?”

北方的奥德赛: “不是你，是你的伙计，他是个牧师，在帕斯提里克，很久以前。他问我有没有见过你，马尔穆特·基德。他给了我一些吃的。我在那里没有呆很长时间。你有没有听他说起过我？”
An Odyssey of the North: “No; your partner, him priest, Pastilik, long time ago.Him ask me if I see you, Malemute Kid.Him give me grub.I no stop long.You hear him speak ‘bout me?”

北方的奥德赛: “哦！你就是那个拿海獭皮换狗的人吗？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Oh! you ’re the fellow that traded the otter skins for the dogs?”

北方的奥德赛: 那个人点点头，敲出烟斗里的灰，然后裹紧毛皮衣，表示他不想继续往下谈了。马尔穆特·基德把那盏油灯吹灭，和普林斯一起钻进毯子里去了。
An Odyssey of the North: The man nodded, knocked out his pipe, and signified his disinclination for conversation by rolling up in his furs.Malemute Kid blew out the slush-lamp and crawled under the blankets with Prince.

北方的奥德赛: “那么，他是什么人呢？”
An Odyssey of the North: “Well, what is he?”

北方的奥德赛: “不知道——不知道怎么回事，他把我引到别的话题上了，然后就像蛤蜊一样闭上了嘴。但这是个会激起人好奇心的家伙。我听说过他。八年前，沿海地区的人就对他很好奇。有点儿神秘，你知道。在严冬里，他从离这里有上千英里的北部，一路沿着白令海峡赶到这里，就像有魔鬼追着他似的。没有人知道他是从什么地方来的，但是可以肯定的是，他一定来自遥远的地方。他到戈洛文湾的时候已经精疲力尽了，他从瑞典牧师那里弄了些吃的，还打探了到南方来的路。这些事，我们都是事后听说的。后来，他放弃了海岸线，径直从诺顿湾渡过来。天气极其恶劣，经常是狂风暴雪，但是他挺过来了，要是换成别人，就算有一千个人，也早没命了。因为错过了在圣·迈克尔登陆，他就在帕斯提里克上岸了。他什么都没了，只剩两条狗，自己险些就给饿死了。
An Odyssey of the North: “Don’t know—turned me off, somehow, and then shut up like a clam.But he ’s a fellow to whet your curiosity.I’ve heard of him.All the Coast wondered about him eight years ago.Sort of mysterious, you know.He came down out of the North, in the dead of winter, many a thousand miles from here, skirting Bering Sea and traveling as though the devil were after him.No one ever learned where he came from, but he must have come far.He was badly travel-worn when he got food from the Swedish missionary on Golovin Bay and asked the way south.We heard of this afterward.Then he abandoned the shore-line, heading right across Norton Sound.Terrible weather, snowstorms and high winds, but he pulled through where a thousand other men would have died, missing St.Michael’s and making the land at Pastilik.He’d lost all but two dogs, and was nearly gone with starvation.

北方的奥德赛: “鲁博神父见他急着赶路，就给了他一些吃的；但是不能送给他狗，因为等我到了以后，神父自己也要出门。尤利西斯先生清楚地知道，没有狗是没法上路的，因此他烦躁了好几天。他雪橇上有一捆硝得不错的海獭皮，你知道，它们可是跟金子一样贵重呢。那个时候，帕斯提里克有一个俄国生意人，老夏洛克，他有几条狗准备要宰了。这笔生意很快就做成了，等这个古怪的人再往南去的时候，他的雪橇前面已经有一群疾速奔跑的狗了。而夏洛克先生也得到了那捆海獭皮。我见过的，非常不错。我们算了一下，每条狗给他赚了至少五百块钱。不是说这个古怪的人不晓得海獭皮的价钱；某种程度上说，他是个印第安人，从他讲的那寥寥数语中，还能听出他曾和白人一起呆过。
An Odyssey of the North: “He was so anxious to go on that Father Roubeau fitted him out with grub; but he couldn’t let him have any dogs, for he was only waiting my arrival to go on a trip himself.Mr. Ulysses knew too much to start on without animals, and fretted around for several days.He had on his sled a bunch of beautifully cured otter skins, sea-otters, you know, worth their weight in gold.There was also at Pastilik an old Shylock of a Russian trader, who had dogs to kill.Well, they didn’t dicker very long, but when the Strange One headed south again, it was in the rear of a spanking dog-team.Mr. Shylock, by the way, had the otter skins.I saw them, and they were magnificent.We figured it up and found the dogs brought him at least five hundred apiece.And it wasn’t as if the Strange One didn’t know the value of sea-otter; he was an Indian of some sort, and what little he talked showed he’d been among white men.

北方的奥德赛: “海面上的冰消融以后，从努尼瓦克岛传来消息说，他去那里找过吃的。然后他就消失了，这是八年里第一次又听到他的消息。那么如今，他是从什么地方来的呢？他在那里做了些什么？他又是为什么离开那里的呢？他是一个印第安人，他去过别人都不知道的地方，还接受过训练，这对于一个印第安人而言，是不常见的。这又是一个需要你来解决的北方的奥秘，普林斯。”
An Odyssey of the North: “After the ice passed out of the Sea, word came up from Nunivak Island that he’d gone in there for grub.Then he dropped from sight, and this is the first heard of him in eight years.Now where did he come from? and what was he doing there? and why did he come from there?He’s Indian, he’s been nobody knows where, and he’s had discipline, which is unusual for an Indian.Another mystery of the North for you to solve, Prince.”

北方的奥德赛: “太感谢你了，但是如今我手头上需要解决的事情太多了。”他回答道。
An Odyssey of the North: “Thanks, awfully; but I’ve got too many on hand as it is,” he replied.

北方的奥德赛: 马尔穆特·基德已经睡着了；但是这位年轻的采矿工程师依旧睁着眼睛，在黑暗中注视着上方，等着那股莫名其妙的、令他血液翻腾的兴奋劲儿渐渐平静。等他睡着以后，他的大脑还在不停地活动，在那一段时间里，他仿佛也在那种谁都不知道的雪地里游荡，在没有尽头的路上和狗一起艰难跋涉着，还看见了人们在生活，辛苦工作，最后像男子汉一样死去。
An Odyssey of the North: Malemute Kid was already breathing heavily; but the young mining engineer gazed straight up through the thick darkness, waiting for the strange orgasm which stirred his blood to die away.And when he did sleep, his brain worked on, and for the nonce he, too, wandered through the white unknown, struggled with the dogs on endless trails, and saw men live, and toil, and die like men.

北方的奥德赛: 第二天早上，天未破晓，邮差和警察们便前往道森。但是代表女王陛下的利益，代她左右百姓命运的机构，却不让这些邮差们歇息；过了一个星期，他们又出现在斯图尔特河边，载着沉甸甸的运往盐湖的信件。不过，他们的狗倒是换了一批新的；但是，它们是狗。
An Odyssey of the North: The next morning, hours before daylight, the dog-drivers and policemen pulled out for Dawson.But the powers that saw to her Majesty’s interests, and ruled the destinies of her lesser creatures, gave the mailmen little rest; for a week later they appeared at Stuart River, heavily burdened with letters for Salt Water.However, their dogs had been replaced by fresh ones; but then, they were dogs.

北方的奥德赛: 这些人原本盼望能停留几天，好歇息一下；而且，克朗代克又是北部的一个新地区，他们早就盼着能见识见识这个金沙似水、舞厅里狂欢不止的黄金城市。但是，如今他们几乎跟上次来时一样，烘着袜子，吸着烟。不过，他们当中有一两个胆子大的已经有了逃跑的念头，正盘算着能不能穿过没被开发过的落基山脉去往东部，然后沿着麦肯齐山谷，走到他们喜欢且常去的老地方——契帕文一带。有两三个人甚至打定主意，在任职期满以后一起顺着那条路回家。他们立即开始制定计划，期待着这番冒险，就像一个在城市长大的人渴望到森林里度过一天假期一样。
An Odyssey of the North: The men had expected some sort of a lay-over in which to rest up; besides, this Klondike was a new section of the Northland, and they had wished to see a little something of the Golden City where dust flowed like water, and dance halls rang with never ending revelry.But they dried their socks and smoked their evening pipes with much the same gusto as on their former visit, though one or two bold spirits speculated on desertion and the possibility of crossing the unexplored Rockies to the east, and thence, by the Mackenzie Valley, of gaining their old stamping-grounds in the Chippewyan Country.Two or three even decided to return to their homes by that route when their terms of service had expired, and they began to lay plans forthwith, looking forward to the hazardous undertaking in much the same way a city-bred man would to a day’s holiday in the woods.

北方的奥德赛: 那个用海獭皮换狗的人显得心神不宁，尽管他对这样的讨论没有半点儿兴趣，后来，他把马尔穆特·基德拉到一边，小声说了一会儿话。普林斯好奇地盯着他们，后来，他们竟然戴上帽子和手套出去了，这情形就更加神秘了。他们回来以后，马尔穆特·基德把他的称金子的秤搁到桌子上，称了六十盎司的金子，放进那个古怪的人的袋子里。然后，邮差们的头儿也加入了他们的秘密会谈，而且还跟他做了某种买卖。第二天，这群人沿河而上，而那个用海獭皮换狗的人却带着几磅吃的，返回道森去了。
An Odyssey of the North: He of the Otter Skins seemed very restless, though he took little interest in the discussion, and at last he drew Malemute Kid to one side and talked for some time in low tones.Prince cast curious eyes in their direction, and the mystery deepened when they put on caps and mittens, and went outside.When they returned, Malemute Kid placed his gold-scales on the table, weighed out the matter of sixty ounces, and transferred them to the Strange One’s sack.Then the chief of the dog-drivers joined the conclave, and certain business was transacted with him.The next day the gang went on up river, but He of the Otter Skins took several pounds of grub and turned his steps back toward Dawson.

北方的奥德赛: 普林斯问他的时候，马尔穆特·基德说：“我也搞不清到底是怎么回事；反正这个可怜的人肯定是有什么原因才不想干了的——至少对他来说是一个很重要的原因，但是他不愿意让别人知道。你明白的，做这种活计就跟当兵一样；他签了两年，要想离开就得把自己赎岀来。他不能擅离职守后再留在这里，而且他发了疯似的想留在这里。他说，他刚到道森就拿定主意了；但是他跟谁都不认识，身上没一分钱，也就只跟我一个人说过两句话。所以，他就跟副总督谈了一下，而且说好，要是他能从我这里弄到钱就办理退职——就是跟我借钱，你知道的。他说一年之内就能还我，假如我愿意的话，他可以给我指条财路。他从没去过那里，但是他知道那里很富有。
An Odyssey of the North: “Didn’t know what to make of it,” said Malemute Kid in response to Prince’s queries; “but the poor beggar wanted to be quit of the service for some reason or other—at least it seemed a most important one to him, though he wouldn’t let on what.You see, it’s just like the army; he signed for two years, and the only way to get free was to buy himself out.He couldn’t desert and then stay here, and he was just wild to remain in the country.Made up his mind when he got to Dawson, he said; but no one knew him, hadn’t a cent, and I was the only one he’d spoken two words with.So he talked it over with the Lieutenant-Governor, and made arrangements in case he could get the money from me—loan, you know.Said he’d pay back in the year, and if I wanted, would put me onto something rich.Never’d seen it, but knew it was rich.

北方的奥德赛: “听我说！哎，他把我拉到外边的时候都快哭了。他苦苦哀求，还在雪地里给我跪下，直到我把他拽起来。他像疯子一样唠叨了好久。他还发誓说自己为了实现这个目标已经受了很多年的苦，这次愿望要是落空，他可承受不了。我问他有什么目的，他不肯说。他说，他们可能会把他分配到这条路的另外半段上工作，那样两年之内他就回不了道森了，那时候就太晚了。我这辈子，还没见过有人这么难过呢。等我同意把金子借给他的时候，我又只好把他从雪地里拽起来。我对他说，这些钱就当是我的股份好了。你以为他答应了吗？没有，老兄！他发誓说会把找到的东西全给我，让我富得连做梦都不敢想，反正他反反复复说的就是这些话。通常，一个长期给投资人拼命的人，如果得到了什么，往往连一半都舍不得分给那个投资人的。普林斯，这背后肯定有什么事情，你可记好了。要是他还在这一带的话，我们肯定会听说关于他的事情的……”
An Odyssey of the North: “And talk! why, when he got me outside he was ready to weep.Begged and pleaded; gotdown in the snow to me till I hauled him out of it.Palavered around like a crazy man.Swore he’s worked to this very end for years and years, and couldn’t bear to be disappointed now.Asked him what end, but he wouldn’t say.Said they might keep him on the other half of the trail and he would n’t get to Dawson in two years, and then it would be too late.Never saw a man take on so in my life.And when I said I ’d let him have it, had to yank him out of the snow again.Told him to consider it in the light of a grub-stake.Think he’d have it?No, sir!Swore he ’d give me all he found, make me rich beyond the dreams of avarice, and all such stuff.Now a man who puts his life and time against a grub-stake ordinarily finds it hard enough to turn over half of what he finds.Something behind all this, Prince; just you make a note of it.We’ll hear of him if he stays in the country”—

北方的奥德赛: “那假如他不呆在这一带呢？”
An Odyssey of the North: “And if he doesn’t?”

北方的奥德赛: “那就全当我的善心没得到好报，白白没了六十多盎司金子。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Then my good nature gets a shock, and I’m sixty some odd ounces out.”

北方的奥德赛: 寒冷的天气伴随着漫长的黑夜一起到来了，太阳也沿着雪地南面的地平线像往常一样玩起了古老的遮脸的游戏，但是马尔穆特·基德垫出去的那笔钱还是没有一点儿消息。后来，在一月初的一个阴冷的早上，很多狗拉着几架满载的雪橇来到他那个位于斯图尔特河下游的小木屋前。那个用海獭皮换狗的人真的来了，和他一起来的还有另外一个人，那样的身材可能上帝也忘了当初是怎么创造出来的了。大家只要讲到幸运、勇气和一铁锹五百美元的金沙，都会想到阿克塞尔·冈德森这个名字；大伙要是围着营火，说起关于胆量、力气和勇猛的故事，那也肯定要说一说他的事情。而且，每当大家少了谈话的兴致，只要提到跟他有福同享有难同当的那个女人，大家的谈话就又会热烈起来。
An Odyssey of the North: The cold weather had come on with the long nights, and the sun had begun to play his ancient game of peekaboo along the southern snow-line ere aught was heard of Malemute Kid’s grub-stake.And then, one bleak morning in early January, a heavily laden dog-train pulled into his cabin below Stuart River.He of the Otter Skins was there, and with him walked a man such as the gods have almost forgotten how to fashion.Men never talked of luck and pluck and five-hundred-dollar dirt without bringing in the name of Axel Gunderson; nor could tales of nerve or strength or daring pass up and down the camp-fire without the summoning of his presence.And when the conversation flagged, it blazed anew at mention of the woman who shared his fortunes.

北方的奥德赛: 前边已经提到过，上帝在创造阿克塞尔·冈德森的时候，想起了他们古时候的手艺，就模仿着洪荒时期的人把他创造出来。他身材高大，足有七英尺高，穿一身漂亮的衣服，就像一位黄金国国王。他的胸膛、脖子和四肢，都和巨人的一样。因为得支撑他重达三百磅的骨头和肌肉，他的雪地鞋要比别人的长一码多。他的脸很粗糙，额头上布满皱纹，下巴宽大，两只浅蓝色的眼睛毫不畏缩，他的这张脸告诉人们他是一个只知道强横霸道的人。他那结了霜的头发，黄得好像熟透了的玉米穗，好像白天横扫黑夜一样，一直披散到他的熊皮大衣上。他在前面领着狗从狭窄的小路上大摇大摆地走过来的模样，隐约透露着一种习惯了海上生活的人的习性；他拿狗鞭子的柄敲打马尔穆特·基德家的门时，就像一个到南方抢劫并狠命进攻城堡大门的北欧海盗。普林斯露着他女人似的胳膊，揉着发酵了的生面团，同时还不停地瞟着这三位客人——三位这样的客人一起走进一个人的家，真是一辈子也难遇见的事。那个被马尔穆特·基德叫做尤利西斯的怪人，依然吸引着他；但是，最吸引他的却是阿克赛尔·冈德森和他的老婆。她走了一天的路，感觉疲惫，因为在他丈夫因得到寒带的金矿矿苗而发迹以后的日子里，她的身体就在舒适惬意的小木屋里变软了。她靠在她丈夫宽厚的胸膛上，就像一株柔嫩的鲜花倚着墙一样，她懒洋洋地回应着马尔穆特·基德善意的逗弄，偶尔用她那深邃的黑眼睛瞟普林斯一眼，使得普林斯莫名其妙地激动起来。因为普林斯是个男人，身体健康，他已经有几个月没怎么见过女人了。而且，她年纪比他大，还是个印第安人。不过，她跟他见过的所有土著女人都不同：她去过很远的地方——他从他们的谈话里了解到她去过很多国家，包括他的故乡；白种女人知道的事情，她差不多都知道，另外她还懂很多女人不该懂的事情。她能把鱼干做成一顿饭，也能在雪地里搭一个床铺；但是她有意逗弄他们，细细描述着精美的食物，提起各种各样他们几乎淡忘的菜肴，搞得他们的肚子都在抗议了。她晓得驼鹿、熊、小蓝狐和北方海里那些野生两栖动物的习性；她对森林里和江河上的事情无所不知，不管人、鸟还是野兽在柔软的雪面上留下什么痕迹，她都一眼就能看出来；普林斯还留意到她看宿营规定时，眼里露出赞赏的目光。这些规定是那个本性难改的贝特尔斯一时兴起制定出来的，语言简洁、诙谐。普林斯总是在女士来以前就把它翻过去，冲着墙；但是谁能想到这个土著女人会……好吧，如今已经晚了。
An Odyssey of the North: As has been noted, in the making of Axel Gunderson the gods had remembered their old-time cunning, and cast him after the manner of men who were born when the world was young.Full seven feet he towered in his picturesque costume which marked a king of Eldorado.His chest, neck, and limbs were those of a giant.To bear his three hundred pounds of bone and muscle, his snowshoes were greater by a generous yard than those of other men.Rough-hewn, with rugged brow and massive jaw and unflinching eyes of palest blue, his face told the tale of one who knew but the law of might.Of the yellow of ripe corn silk, his frost-incrusted hair swept like day across the night, and fell far down his coat of bear-skin.A vague tradition of the sea seemed to cling about him, as he swung down the narrow trail in advance of the dogs; and he brought the butt of his dog-whip against Malemute Kid’s door as a Norse sea rover, on southern foray, might thunder for admittance at the castle gate.Prince bared his womanly arms and kneaded sour-dough bread, casting, as he did so, many a glance at the three guests,—three guests the like of which might never come under a man’s roof in a lifetime.The Strange One, whom Malemute Kid had surnamed Ulysses, still fascinated him; but his interest chiefly gravitated between Axel Gunderson and Axel Gunderson’s wife.She felt the day’s journey, for she had softened in comfortable cabins during the many days since her husband mastered the wealth of frozen pay-streaks, and she was tired.She rested against his great breast like a slender flower against a wall, replying lazily to Malemute Kid’s good-natured banter, and stirring Prince’s blood strangely with an occasional sweep of her deep, dark eyes.For Prince was a man, and healthy, and had seen few women in many months.And she was older than he, and an Indian besides.But she was different from all native wives he had met: she had traveled,—had been in his country among others, he gathered from the conversation; and she knew most of the things the women of his own race knew, and much more that it was not in the nature of things for them to know.She could make a meal of sun-dried fish or a bed in the snow; yet she teased them with tantalizing details of many-course dinners, and caused strange internal dissensions to arise at the mention of various quondam dishes which they had well-nigh forgotten.She knew the ways of the moose, the bear, and the little blue fox, and of the wild amphibians of the Northern seas; she was skilled in the lore of the woods and the streams, and the tale writ by man and bird and beast upon the delicate snow crust was to her an open book; yet Prince caught the appreciative twinkle in her eye as she read the Rules of the Camp.These rules had been fathered by the Unquenchable Bettles at a time when his blood ran high, and were remarkable for the terse simplicity of their humor.Prince always turned them to the wall before the arrival of ladies; but who could suspect that this native wife—Well, it was too late now.

北方的奥德赛: 那么，阿克赛尔·冈德森的老婆就是这样一个人，她的名声和她丈夫一起，传遍了整个北方。吃饭时，马尔穆特·基德仗着自己是他们的老朋友，逗弄她，普林斯也丢掉了初次见面的羞怯，跟着一起起哄。尽管敌强我弱，但她仍然能坚守阵地，而她的丈夫，笨嘴拙舌，只能笑着给她鼓掌助威。他为有这样一位妻子感到骄傲；他的每一个表情，每一个动作，都表明了她在他生命中占有非常重要的位置。那个用海獭皮换狗的人一声不吭地吃着饭，在这热闹的交战中他已经被遗忘了；其他人还没吃完，他就离开了桌子，到外面和狗呆在一起了。不过，他刚离开，他的同伴们也很快戴上手套，穿好皮大衣，跟着他出去了。
An Odyssey of the North: This, then, was the wife of Axel Gunderson, a woman whose name and fame had traveled with her husband’s, hand in hand, through all the Northland.At table, Malemute Kid baited her with the assurance of an old friend, and Prince shook off the shyness of first acquaintance and joined in.But she held her own in the unequal contest, while her husband, slower in wit, ventured naught but applause.And he was very proud of her; his every look and action revealed the magnitude of the place she occupied in his life.He of the Otter Skins ate in silence, forgotten in the merry battle; and long ere the others were done he pushed back from the table and went out among the dogs.Yet all too soon his fellow travelers drew on their mittens and parkas, and followed him.

北方的奥德赛: 很多天没下雪，雪橇顺着被冻得很结实的育空路一路滑去，就像在光滑的冰面上一样，一点儿都不费力。尤利西斯驾着第一架雪橇，普林斯和阿克赛尔·冈德森的老婆驾着第二架；马尔穆特·基德和那位黄头发的巨人驾着第三架。
An Odyssey of the North: There had been no snow for many days, and the sleds slipped along the hard-packed Yukon trail as easily as if it had been glare ice.Ulysses led the first sled; with the second came Prince and Axel Gunderson’s wife; while Malemute Kid and the yellow-haired giant brought up the third.

北方的奥德赛: “这只是一种‘预感’，基德，”他说，“但是我觉得这事有谱。他从来没去过那里，不过他讲得有板有眼，并且给我看了一张地图，我几年前在库特纳一带就听人说过这张地图。我本打算请你一起去；但是他这个人很古怪，他直截了当地说，要是有别人加入，他就放弃。不过，等我回来以后，我会第一个告诉你，我会把附近的矿给你，再把建造城市的地基分给你一半。
An Odyssey of the North: “It ’s only a ‘hunch,’ Kid,” he said; “but I think it ’s straight.He’s never been there, but he tells a good story, and shows a map I heard of when I was in the Kootenay country years ago.I’d like to have you go along; but he ’s a strange one, and swore point-blank to throw it up if any one was brought in.But when I come back you ’ll get first tip, and I’ll stake you next to me, and give you a half share in the town site besides.

北方的奥德赛: “不！不！”他大叫，因为对方想打断他的话。“这事我做主，在事情没办完之前，需要有个人商议一下。要是这事牢靠的话，那就是第二个克里普尔克甲克了，老兄，你听见了吗？第二个克里普尔克甲克！那可是石英金矿，你要知道，可不是砂矿；要是我们干对了路子，我们就能把整个矿都搞到手——那就是成百上千万了。我过去听说过这个地方，你肯定也听说过。我们要建造一座城镇——雇几千名工人——开一条水路——汽船航道——大笔的运输生意——开向上游的浅水轮船——可能，再勘测一条铁路——几家锯木厂——电厂——还有自己的银行——商业公司——大财团——哎呀！我回来之前，你千万别跟被人讲！”
