北方的奥德赛: “我刚讲过，我和我族里的人不一样，因为我体内流着那个从海外来的壮实的白人的血液。听说，在这两个白人到来之前，我们原本有另外一套规矩；但是这两个人不但凶猛，还爱吵架，他们总是和我们族里的人打架，直到最后，没有人敢跟他们打了。最后，他们自立为酋长，打破了我们以前的规矩，另立了新的规矩，规定男人是他父亲的儿子，而不和我们过去一样，男人是母亲的儿子。他们还规定，第一个生下来的儿子有权利继承他父亲所有的东西，而他的兄弟姐妹就得自谋出路。他们还给我们立了别的规矩。他们教我们用新的方法捕鱼捉熊，我们树林里的熊可多了；他们还教我们多储存东西，以免遇到饥荒。这些都是好事。
An Odyssey of the North: “As I said, I was different from my people, for I carried the strong, strange blood of this white man who came out of the sea.It is said we had other laws in the days before these men; but they were fierce and quarrelsome, and fought with our men till there were no more left who dared to fight.Then they made themselves chiefs, and took away our old laws and gave us new ones, insomuch that the man was the son of his father, and not his mother, as our way had been.They also ruled that the son, firstborn, should have all things which were his father’s before him, and that the brothers and sisters should shift for themselves.And they gave us other laws.They showed us new ways in the catching of fish and the killing of bear which were thick in the woods; and they taught us to lay by bigger stores for the time of famine.And these things were good.

北方的奥德赛: “但是他们当了酋长以后，再没有人敢惹他们了，这两个外来的白人开始互相残杀。其中一个，也就是我继承了他血统的那个人，那时就把刺海豹的鱼叉扎进另外一个人身上有一胳膊深。这样，他们的孩子就不断地斗下去，接着是他们的孩子的孩子；他们非常恨对方，经常互相伤害，甚至到了我这一辈还是这样，以至于每家只有一个人能延续香火。我们家里，只剩下我自己；那一家只剩下一个女儿，叫昂加，和她母亲一起生活。一天夜里，他的父亲和我的父亲出海捕鱼就没有回来；后来，大潮把他们冲上岸，两个人仍然紧紧地扭打在一起。
An Odyssey of the North: “But when they had become chiefs, and there were no more men to face their anger, they fought, these strange white men, each with the other.And the one whose blood I carry drove his seal spear the length of an arm through the other’s body.Their children took up the fight, and their children’s children; and there was great hatred between them, and black doings, even to my time, so that in each family but one lived to pass down the blood of them that went before.Of my blood I was alone; of the other man’s there was but a girl, Unga, who lived with her mother.Her father and my father did not come back from the fishing one night; but afterward they washed up to the beach on the big tides, and they held very close to each other.

北方的奥德赛: “人们都惊讶于我们两家的仇恨，岁数大的人都一边摇头一边说，等她有了孩子，我也有了孩子，这个仗还要打下去。我小的时候他们就这么跟我讲，直到后来我也信了，把昂加看做是仇人，认为以后她的孩子一定会跟我的孩子打仗。我每天都在想这些事，等到我长大了，我就问他们为什么一定要到这种地步。他们答道：‘我们不知道，只知道你们的父辈就是这么做的。’我很纳闷，死了的人打的仗竟然非得让后来的人接着打下去，而且我确实不知道有什么道理可言。但是大家都说必须得这样，而我当时还不过是个小伙子。
An Odyssey of the North: “The people wondered, because of the hatred between the houses, and the old men shook their heads and said the fight would go on when children were born to her and children to me.They told me this as a boy, till I came to believe, and to look upon Unga as a foe, who was to be the mother of children which were to fight with mine.I thought of these things day by day, and when I grew to a stripling I came to ask why this should be so.And they answered, ‘We do not know, but that in such way your fathers did.’ And I marveled that those which were to come should fight the battles of those that were gone, and in it I could see no right.But the people said it must be, and I was only a stripling.

北方的奥德赛: “他们还说，我必须抓紧，这样我的孩子就会比她的孩子先成熟，先壮实起来。这很简单，我是酋长，因为我祖先的功绩和他们立下的规矩，以及我自己的财产，大家都很尊重我。什么样的姑娘都愿意嫁给我，但是我一个也看不上。那些年纪大的人和那些姑娘的母亲都催我要抓紧，因为那个时候很多猎手正向昂加的母亲开出大宗的聘礼；要是她的孩子比我的孩子壮实得早的话，我的孩子肯定会没命的。
An Odyssey of the North: “And they said I must hurry, that my blood might be the older and grow strong before hers.This was easy, for I was head man, and the people looked up to me because of the deeds and the laws of my fathers, and the wealth which was mine.Any maiden would come to me, but I found none to my liking.And the old men and the mothers of maidens told me to hurry, for even then were the hunters bidding high to the mother of Unga; and should her children grow strong before mine, mine would surely die.

北方的奥德赛: “我还是没有选中一位称心的姑娘，直到有一天傍晚我捕鱼回来。太阳正要落山，低沉的日光照射着我的眼睛，风很顺，几只皮船乘着白色的海浪疾驰过来。突然昂加的皮船从我旁边驶过，她看了我一眼，她乌黑的头发飘舞着，像黑夜的云彩，脸颊被浪花打得湿漉漉的。我刚讲过，太阳光照着我的眼睛，我还是个小伙子；但是不知怎么回事，我恍然大悟，这就是所谓的情投意合。等她划船前进的时候，刚划了两下，又回过头来看我——只有昂加这样的女人才会这样看人——我知道这还是那样的表示。我们超过那些慢吞吞的大皮船，把它们远远落在后面的时候，大家都替我们叫好。但是她快速地划着桨，我的心像一张满帆，不过我没赶上她。风力变强了，海上是雪白的浪，船像海豹一样迎风飞驰，我们朝着海面上那缕金色的阳光呼啸而去。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Nor did I find a maiden till one night coming back from the fishing.The sunlight was lying, so, low and full in the eyes, the wind free, and the kayaks racing with the white seas.Of a sudden the kayak of Unga came driving past me, and she looked upon me, so, with her black hair flying like a cloud of night and the spray wet on her cheek.As say, the sunlight was full in the eyes, and I was a stripling; but somehow it was all clear, and I knew it to be the call of kind to kind.As she whipped ahead she looked back within the space of two strokes,—looked as only the woman Unga could look,—and again I knew it as the call of kind.The people shouted as we ripped past the lazy oomiaks and left them far behind.But she was quick at the paddle, and my heart was like the belly of a sail, and I did not gain.The wind freshened, the sea whitened, and, leaping like the seals on the windward breech, we roared down the golden pathway of the sun.”

北方的奥德赛: 纳斯弯着身子，已有一半身体离开了凳子，他摆出一副划桨的姿势，就像又在比赛一样。在炉子对面的某个地方，他似乎看到了那只上下颠簸的橡皮船和昂加飞扬的头发。他的耳朵似乎听见了风声，鼻孔里似乎也充满了海水的咸味。
An Odyssey of the North: Naass was crouched half out of his stool, in the attitude of one driving a paddle, as he ran the race anew.Somewhere across the stove he beheld the tossing kayak and the flying hair of Unga.The voice of the wind was in his ears, and its salt beat fresh upon his nostrils.

北方的奥德赛: “但是她上岸了，跑到沙滩上，笑着跑回她母亲的房子。那一晚，我有了一个极好的想法——一个无愧是阿卡屯全体人民领袖的想法。于是，当月亮升起的时候，我就来到她母亲的房子前边，看了看雅希—奴希堆在她门前的那些东西——这是雅希—奴希的聘礼，他是一个身体强壮的猎手，想当昂加孩子的父亲。其他几个年轻人也曾把东西堆在那里，后来又拿走了；而且每个年轻人堆放的东西都比前边的小伙子堆放得多一些。
An Odyssey of the North: “But she made the shore, and ran up the sand, laughing, to the house of her mother.And a great thought came to me that night,—a thought worthy of him that was chief over all the people of Akatan.So, when the moon was up, I went down to the house of her mother, and looked upon the goods of Yash-Noosh, which were piled by the door,—the goods of Yash-Noosh, a strong hunter who had it in mind to be the father of the children of Unga.Other young men had piled their goods there, and taken them away again; and each young man had made a pile greater than the one before.

北方的奥德赛: “我对着月亮和星星笑了起来，回到自己的房子里，那里储存着我的财产。我搬了好几趟，直到我的东西比雅希—奴希的那堆高出一只手为止。那里有晒干的鱼和烟熏的鱼；有海豹皮四十张，毛皮二十张，每张皮都扎着口，肚子里是满满的鱼油；还有熊皮十张，那是春天熊出现时我在树林子里打回来的。那里还有珠子、毛毯和鲜红色的布，这些都是我和东边的人换来的，而他们又是和住在更东边的人换来的。我看着雅希—奴希的那一堆东西笑了；因为我是阿卡屯的酋长，我的财产比那些小伙子的都多，我的祖先们曾立下功绩，还立了很多规矩，使得他们的名字流芳百世。
An Odyssey of the North: “And I laughed to the moon and the stars, and went to my own house where my wealth was stored.And many trips I made, till my pile was greater by the fingers of one hand than the pile of Yash-Noosh.There were fish, dried in the sun and smoked; and forty hides of the hair seal, and half as many of the fur, and each hide was tied at the mouth and big-bellied with oil; and ten skins of bear which I killed in the woods when they came out in the spring.And there were beads and blankets and scarlet cloths, such as I got in trade from the people who lived to the east, and who got them in trade from the people who lived still beyond in the east.And I looked upon the pile of Yash-Noosh and laughed; for I was head man in Akatan, and my wealth was greater than the wealth of all my young men, and my fathers had done deeds, and given laws, and put their names for all time in the mouths of the people.

北方的奥德赛: “所以天刚亮，我就到沙滩上去，用余光看着昂加母亲的房子。我的聘礼还原封不动地堆在那里。女人们都在笑，还偷偷地议论着。我很纳闷，因为从没有一个人出过这么多聘礼；那天晚上，我又多放了一些东西，还在旁边放了一只从没出过海的、硝得很好的皮舟。但是到白天的时候它还是堆在那里，成了所有人的笑柄。昂加的母亲太狡猾了，我很生气，我不能在我族人的面前受这样的羞辱。所以，当天晚上我又放了很多东西，让它成了大大的一堆，另外，我还把我的大皮船也拖到了岸上，这只船可抵得上二十只皮舟。于是，清晨的时候，那堆东西都不见了。
An Odyssey of the North: “So, when the morning came, I went down to the beach, casting out of the corner of my eye at the house of the mother of Unga.My offer yet stood untouched.And the women smiled, and said sly things one to the other.I wondered, for never had such a price been offered; and that night I added more to the pile, and put beside it a kayak of well-tanned skins which never yet had swam in the sea.But in the day it was yet there, open to the laughter of all men.The mother of Unga was crafty, and I grew angry at the shame in which I stood before my people.So that night I added till it became a great pile, and I hauled up my oomiak, which was of the value of twenty kayaks.And in the morning there was no pile.

北方的奥德赛: “然后我就开始准备婚礼，连住在东边的人都来了，因为宴会上的食物很丰盛，还有送给客人的礼物。昂加比我年纪大，大四个太阳，这是我们计算年龄的方式。我只是个小伙子；不过我是酋长，还是酋长的儿子，因此也没什么问题。
An Odyssey of the North: “Then made I preparation for the wedding, and the people that lived even to the east came for the food of the feast and the potlach token.Unga was older than I by the age of four suns in the way we reckoned the years.I was only a stripling; but then I was a chief, and the son of a chief, and it did not matter.

北方的奥德赛: “但是有一艘船从海平面上露出帆来，在风的推动下，船越来越近了。船的排水口处正淌出清清的水，船上的人正在急急忙忙地拼命抽动水泵。一个身材魁梧的人站在船头，一边瞧着水的深浅，一边下命令，他声如洪钟。他淡蓝色的眼睛像深水一样，他的头发像海狮的鬃毛。而且，他的头发是黄颜色的，就像南方人收割的稻草，又像是水手编织的马尼拉麻绳。
An Odyssey of the North: “But a ship shoved her sails above the floor of the ocean, and grew larger with the breath of the wind.From her scuppers she ran clear water, and the men were in haste and worked hard at the pumps.On the bow stood a mighty man, watching the depth of the water and giving commands with a voice of thunder.His eyes were of the pale blue of the deep waters, and his head was maned like that of a sea lion.And his hair was yellow, like the straw of a southern harvest or the manila rope-yarns which sailormen plait.

北方的奥德赛: “前些年，我们也见过很多从远方来的大船，但是这艘船是第一个在阿卡屯靠岸的。宴会停止了，女人和孩子们都跑回家里，而我们这些男人都拉好了弓，手持长矛，等着那伙人过来。但是，船头靠上岸以后，那些陌生人根本没注意到我们，他们在忙活自己的事情。潮退了以后，他们就把这艘双桅帆船翻过来，开始修补船底的那个大窟窿。就这样，女人们都又悄悄回来了，宴会继续。
An Odyssey of the North: “Of late years we had seen ships from afar, but this was the first to come to the beach of Akatan.The feast was broken, and the women and children fled to the houses, while we men strung our bows and waited with spears in hand.But when the ship’s forefoot smelt the beach the strange men took no notice of us, being busy with their own work.With the falling of the tide they careened the schooner and patched a great hole in her bottom.So the women crept back, and the feast went on.

北方的奥德赛: “等到涨潮的时候，那伙漂泊在海上的人就在海水较深的地方抛下了锚，接着便来到我们中间。他们拿来一些礼物，态度也很友好；所以我就给他们腾了些地方，而且像对待其他客人一样，也很大方地送了他们一些礼物；因为这是我成亲的日子，何况我还是阿卡屯的酋长。那个头发像海狮鬃毛一样的男人也来了，他长得又高又壮，让人觉得他的脚一踩下去，地面都会颤抖一样。他双臂交叉放在胸前，总是直勾勾地盯着昂加看，就这样，一直到太阳下山、星星出现的时候。然后他才回到自己的船上。之后，我就拉着昂加，把她带到我家。大家在我家里又唱又笑，女人们开着玩笑，就像女人们平常在婚礼上那样。但是我们并不在意。最后，大家留下我们两个人，各自回家了。
An Odyssey of the North: “When the tide rose, the sea wanderers kedged the schooner to deep water, and then came among us.They bore presents and were friendly; so I made room for them, and out of the largeness of my heart gave them tokens such as I gave all the guests; for it was my wedding day, and I was head man in Akatan.And he with the mane of the sea lion was there, so tall and strong that one looked to see the earth shake with the fall of his feet.He looked much and straight at Unga, with his arms folded, so, and stayed till the sun went away and the stars came out.Then he went down to his ship.After that I took Unga by the hand and led her to my own house.And there was singing and great laughter, and the women said sly things, after the manner of women at such times.But we did not care.Then the people left us alone and went home.

北方的奥德赛: “喧闹的声音还没有消失，那群海上漂泊的人的首领就走进门来。他手里拿着几个黑瓶子，我们一起喝着瓶子里的东西，喝得很尽兴。你要知道，我那时不过是个小伙子，又一直生活在世界的尽头。因此，我的血液热得像火，我的心轻飘飘的，就像是从浪头飞到峭壁上的泡沫一样。昂加安静地坐在角落里一堆皮子上，她大睁着眼睛，仿佛有些害怕。那个头发像海豹鬃毛的家伙，就一直直勾勾地盯着她看，看了好久。后来他的人进来了，带着一捆捆的货物，他把这些货物堆到我跟前，这些都是阿卡屯没有的东西。货物有大小不一的枪支，有火药、子弹和炮弹，有亮闪闪的斧子、钢刀和灵巧的工具，还有很多我从来没看到过的古里古怪的东西。当时，他用手势告诉我，这些东西都归我了，我觉得他这么慷慨，真是个伟大的人；但是他又告诉我，得让昂加上他的船，和他一起离开。你明白吗？——让昂加上他的船跟他走。我祖宗的血液突然间变得滚烫，我拿起长矛，想把他的身体刺穿。但是瓶子里的烈酒已经让我胳膊上失去了力气，他揪住我的脖子，就这样，把我的头往房子里的墙上撞去。我被撞得毫无力气，就像一个刚出生的孩子，两条腿都站不稳了。当他把昂加往门口拽的时候，昂加尖叫着，同时用手乱抓房子里的东西，弄得那些东西在我们周围倒了一地。后来，他用他那粗壮的胳膊把昂加抱了起来，她撕扯着他的黄头发，但是他却像一只在发情期的大雄海豹一样放声大笑。
An Odyssey of the North: “The last noise had not died away, when the chief of the sea wanderers came in by the door.And he had with him black bottles, from which we drank and made merry.You see, I was only a stripling, and had lived all my days on the edge of the world.So my blood became as fire, and my heart as light as the froth that flies from the surf to the cliff.Unga sat silent among the skins in the corner, her eyes wide, for she seemed to fear.And he with the mane of the sea lion looked upon her straight and long.Then his men came in with bundles of goods, and he piled before me wealth such as was not in all Akatan.There were guns, both large and small, and powder and shot and shell, and bright axes and knives of steel, and cunning tools, and strange things the like of which I had never seen.When he showed me by sign that it was all mine, I thought him a great man to be so free; but, he showed me also that Unga was to go away with him in his ship.Do you understand?—that Unga was to go away with him in his ship.The blood of my fathers flamed hot on the sudden, and I made to drive him through with my spear.But the spirit of the bottles had stolen the life from my arm, and he took me by the neck, so, and knocked my head against the wall of the house.And I was made weak like a newborn child, and my legs would no more stand under me.Unga screamed, and she laid hold of the things of the house with her hands, till they fell all about us as he dragged her to the door.Then he took her in his great arms, and when she tore at his yellow hair laughed with a sound like that of the big bull seal in the rut.

北方的奥德赛: “我爬到沙滩上把我的族人叫出来；但是他们都怕那伙人。只有雅希—奴希是个堂堂正正的男子汉，但是那伙人拿桨打他的头，直打得他脸朝下伏在沙滩上，不能动弹为止。然后，他们便扬起帆，唱着歌，借着风势把船开走了。
An Odyssey of the North: “I crawled to the beach and called upon my people; but they were afraid.Only Yash-Noosh was a man, and they struck him on the head with an oar, till he lay with his face in the sand anddid not move.And they raised the sails to the sound of their songs, and the ship went away on the wind.

北方的奥德赛: “大家都说，这样也好，这样阿卡屯就不会再有打仗流血的事了；但是我一句话都没说，一直等到月圆的那天，我把鱼和油放到皮舟上，往东边走了。我看见许多岛和许多人，我这个在世界尽头生活的人，到这一刻才知道世界居然这么大。我用手势跟他们交谈；但是他们根本没看见过什么双桅船，也没有看见过那个头发像海豹鬃毛的家伙，他们始终指着东面。我在各种奇怪的地方睡觉，吃了各类罕见的食物，看见了各种陌生的面孔。许多人都笑话我，以为我脑子有毛病；但是有时候，一些年纪大的人会让我对着阳光，为我祈福；还有一些年轻女人，在她们询问我那只外来的船、昂加和那些海上来的人时，她们的眼里透着温柔。
An Odyssey of the North: “The people said it was good, for there would be no more war of the bloods in Akatan; but I said never a word, waiting till the time of the full moon, when I put fish and oil in my kayak, and went away to the east.I saw many islands and many people, and I, who had lived on the edge, saw that the world was very large.I talked by signs; but they had not seen a schooner nor a man with the mane of a sea lion, and they pointed always to the east.And I slept in queer places, and ate odd things, and met strange faces.Many laughed, for they thought me light of head; but sometimes old men turned my face to the light and blessed me, and the eyes of the young women grew soft as they asked me of the strange ship, and Unga, and the men of the sea.

北方的奥德赛: “就这样，我越过波涛汹涌的大海，顶着狂风暴雨，来到了乌纳拉斯卡。那里有两艘双桅船，但是没有一艘是我要找的。所以，我继续往东走，我眼前的世界也变得越来越大。但是不管在乌纳莫克岛、科迪亚克岛，还是在阿托格纳岛，都没有一点儿关于那艘船的消息。一天，我到了一个有很多岩石的地方，那里的人们在山里挖了很多大洞。那里有一艘双桅帆船，但不是我要找的那艘，那些人把他们挖出来的石块往船上搬。我觉得这种事情像小孩子的把戏，因为这世上到处都是岩石；但是他们给我吃的，还硬让我干活。等到船吃水深的时候，船长给了我些钱，让我离开；我问他要去哪里，他指着南方。我打着手势说，我想跟他一起走；他先笑了笑，后来，因为船上缺人手，他就让我呆在船上帮忙干活。于是，我就学着他们的腔调说话，帮忙拽锚索，在突然刮起大风的时候收起绷紧的帆，而且还轮班掌舵。但是这也不奇怪，因为我的祖先本来就和这些海上的人是一个血统。
An Odyssey of the North: “And in this manner, through rough seas and great storms, came to Unalaska.There were two schooners there, but neither was the one I sought.So I passed on to the east, with the world growing ever larger, and in the Island of Unamok there was no word of the ship, nor in Kadiak, nor in Atognak.And so I came one day to a rocky land, where men dug great holes in the mountain.And there was a schooner, but not my schooner, and men loaded upon it the rocks which they dug.This thought childish, for all the world was made of rocks; but they gave me food and set me to work.When the schooner was deep in the water, the captain gave me money and told me to go; but I asked which way he went, and he pointed south.I made signs that I would go with him; and he laughed at first, but then, being short of men, took me to help work the ship.So I came to talk after their manner, and to heave on ropes, and to reef the stiff sails in sudden squalls, and to take my turn at the wheel.But it was not strange, for the blood of my fathers was the blood of the men of the sea.

北方的奥德赛: “我原本以为，只要我在他那一族人里，很容易就能找到他；一天，我们看到了陆地，我们的船经过海峡，驶入港口，我原来以为，这里的双桅船可能也就我的手指头那么多。但是顺着码头接连几英里都停着这样的船，像很多小鱼挤在一起似的；当我到那些船上打听那个头发像海豹鬃毛的家伙的时候，他们都笑了，用各种不同的语言来回答我。我这才知道，他们来自世界的各个角落。
An Odyssey of the North: “I had thought it an easy task to find him I sought, once I got among his own people; and when we raised the land one day, and passed between a gateway of the sea to a port, I looked for perhaps as many schooners as there were fingers to my hands.But the ships lay against the wharves for miles, packed like so many little fish; and when I went among them to ask for a man with the mane of a sea lion, they laughed, and answered me in the tongues of many peoples.And I found that they hailed from the uttermost parts of the earth.

北方的奥德赛: “于是我进入市区，看着每一个行人的脸。但是他们就像游到岸上的密密麻麻的鳕鱼，不计其数。喧闹声不断袭来，弄得我什么都听不见，那乱糟糟的场面弄得我晕头转向。于是，我继续往前走，走过了那些阳光下歌声飘荡的地方；走过了平原上堆满了丰收的庄稼的地方；还走过了很多大城市，在那里，男人过着女人般的日子，他们嘴里全是假话，因为只想着金子，他们的心都是黑的。但是这个时候，我的族人却在阿卡屯狩猎打鱼，快乐逍遥，以为这世界只是一个小天地。
An Odyssey of the North: “And I went into the city to look upon the face of every man.But they were like the cod when they run thick on the banks, and I could not count them.And the noise smote upon me till I could not hear, and my head was dizzy with much movement.So I went on and on, through the lands which sang in the warm sunshine; where the harvests lay rich on the plains; and where great cities were fat with men that lived like women, with false words in their mouths and their hearts black with the lust of gold.And all the while my people of Akatan hunted and fished, and were happy in the thought that the world was small.

北方的奥德赛: “可是，那次昂加捕鱼回家时看我的眼神总是跟着我，我知道，总有一天我会找到她的。以前，她经常在暮色中到静谧的小路上散步，有的时候还惹得我从那被晨露沾湿的茂密的田野里穿过去追她，她的眼里有默许的意思，只有昂加这样的女人才会有这样的眼神。
An Odyssey of the North: “But the look in the eyes of Unga coming home from the fishing was with me always, and I knew I would find her when the time was met.She walked down quiet lanes in the dusk of the evening, or led me chases across the thick fields wet with the morning dew, and there was a promise in her eyes such as only the woman Unga could give.

北方的奥德赛: “所以我一路游荡，走过了上千座城市。有些人很友好，还给我食物，有些人则嘲笑我，甚至还有人咒骂我；但是我咬紧牙关，仍然行走在陌生的路上，看着各种陌生的景象。有的时候，我，一个酋长，还是酋长的儿子，竟然给人家当苦工——给那些言语粗鲁、铁石心肠的人当苦工，他们从同胞的汗水和悲苦中捞取金子。然而，我还是打听不到任何消息，直到我像一个归巢的海豹似的再次回到海上。但是这次是在另一个港口，在另外一个位于北方的国家。在那里，我听说了一些关于那个黄头发的海上流浪汉的不太具体的传言，我了解到他是个猎捕海豹的，那时候他正在海上行驶。
An Odyssey of the North: “So I wandered through a thousand cities.Some were gentle and gave me food, and others laughed, and still others cursed; but I kept my tongue between my teeth, and went strange ways and saw strange sights.Sometimes, I, who was a chief and the son of a chief, toiled for men,—men rough of speech and hard as iron, who wrung gold from the sweat and sorrow of their fellow men.Yet no word did I get of my quest, till came back to the sea like a homing seal to the rookeries.But this was at another port, in another country which lay to the north.And there heard dim tales of the yellow-haired sea wanderer, and I learned that he was a hunter of seals, and that even then he was abroad on the ocean.

北方的奥德赛: “所以，我就和几个懒散的西瓦希人一起坐上一艘猎捕海豹的双桅船，顺着他那条没有任何痕迹的路线去了北方，当时那里恰是猎捕海豹的旺季。我们在海上呆了几个月，疲惫不堪，我们谈论了很多有关船队的事，还听说了不少有关那个家伙的野蛮行为；但是却一次也没有在海上碰见他。我们接着往北走，一直到了普里比洛夫群岛，我们在沙滩上杀死了成群的海豹，然后把还留有余温的海豹尸体搬到船上，直到船上的排水口淌出来的都是油和血，甲板上站不住人为止。然后便有一艘轮船来追我们，还向我们开炮。但是我们扬起帆，大海冲刷着甲板，将它们洗得干干净净，而我们也在大雾中迷了路。
An Odyssey of the North: “So I shipped on a seal schooner with the lazy Siwashes, and followed his trackless trail to the north where the hunt was then warm.And we were away weary months, and spoke many of the fleet, and heard much of the wild doings of him I sought; but never once did we raise him above the sea.We went north, even to the Pribyloffs, and killed the seals in herds on the beach, and brought their warm bodies aboard till our scuppers ran grease and blood and no man could stand upon the deck.Then were we chased by a ship of slow steam, which fired upon us with great guns.But we put on sail till the sea was over our decks and washed them clean, and lost ourselves in a fog.

北方的奥德赛: “听说，当时，就在我们被吓得心惊肉跳，迅速逃跑的时候，那个黄头发的海上流浪汉恰好来到了普里比洛夫群岛，在岛的左边有一家工厂，他一边叫手下的人扣住公司的员工，一边叫其他的人从工厂里搬出一万张生皮装到船上。我说过，这些事听别人讲的，不过我相信是真的；因为虽然在海上航行的时候没有见过他，但是北方的海上却传遍了他肆意妄为的行为，以至于在那里有属地的三个国家都派船来逮他。我还听到了一些关于昂加的消息，因为船长们都对她赞赏有加，她一直跟那个人在一起。听他们说，她已经学会了过他那种人的日子，还很开心。但是我比谁都了解——我明白她的心是向着阿卡屯那片黄色沙滩上她自己的族人的。
An Odyssey of the North: “It is said, at this time, while we fled with fear at our hearts, that the yellow-haired sea wanderer put into the Pribyloffs, right to the factory, and while the part of his men held the servants of the company, the rest loaded ten thousand green skins from the salt-houses.I say it is said, but I believe; for in the voyages made on the coast with never a meeting, the northern seas rang with his wildness and daring, till the three nations which have lands there sought him with their ships.And I heard of Unga, for the captains sang loud in her praise, and she was always with him.She had learned the ways of his people, they said, and was happy.But I knew better,—knew that her heart harked back to her own people by the yellow beach of Akatan.

北方的奥德赛: “就这样，很久以后，我又回到了那个在海峡附近的港口。刚到那里，我就听人说他已经跨过大洋，到俄罗斯海南面那一带暖和地方的东海岸捕海豹去了。而我，此时已经成了一个水手，和他那一类的人一起坐上船，跟在他后面去捕海豹。那片新的地带没有几艘船；但是整个春天，我们都守在海豹群的附近，把它们赶向北方。后来，母海豹们怀孕了，都游到了俄国的领海区域，我们的人就开始抱怨，感到害怕了。因为那里总是有大雾，坐小船的人每天都有几个消失不见的。他们不愿意干了，所以船长不得不沿着来时的路线返航。但是我知道那个黄头发的海上流浪汉是不会怕的，他会一直守在海豹群附近，甚至会追到俄罗斯群岛，那里可是很少有人去的。于是我就在漆黑的夜晚，趁着放哨的人在船头甲板上打瞌睡的工夫，乘着一只小艇，一个人朝着那个暖和的长岛划去。我一路往南划，遇见江户湾附近的人，他们可是既野蛮又无所畏惧的家伙。吉原的姑娘们都很娇小，皮肤光亮得像钢一样，长得很好看；但是我不能停下来，因为我知道昂加正在北方海豹栖息地附近的海上漂泊。
An Odyssey of the North: “So, after a long time, I went back to the port which is by a gateway of the sea, and there I learned that he had gone across the girth of the great ocean to hunt for the seal to the east of the warm land which runs south from the Russian Seas.And I, who was become a sailorman, shipped with men of his own race, and went after him in the hunt of the seal.And there were few ships off that new land; but we hung on the flank of the seal pack and harried it north through all the spring of the year.And when the cows were heavy with pup and crossed the Russian line, our men grumbled and were afraid.For there was much fog, and every day men were lost in the boats.They would not work, so the captain turned the ship back toward the way it came.But I knew the yellow-haired sea wanderer was unafraid, and would hang by the pack, even to the Russian Isles, where few men go.So I took a boat, in the black of night, when the lookout dozed on the fok’slehead, and went alone to the warm, long land.And I journeyed south to meet the men by Yeddo Bay, who are wild and unafraid.And the Yoshiwara girls were small, and bright like steel, and good to look upon; but I could not stop, for I knew that Unga rolled on the tossing floor by the rookeries of the north.

北方的奥德赛: “江户湾的人来自世界上的各个角落，他们不信神，也没有家，他们的船上都挂着日本国旗。我跟随着他们一起去了富饶的科珀岛，在那里我们的船舱堆满了皮子。一直到我们打算离开，在那片平静的海面上，我们斗没有遇见过一个人。然后，有一天，一股大风吹开了浓浓的雾气，有一艘双桅帆船急匆匆地朝我们驶来，后面紧紧跟着一艘烟囱里冒着浓烟的俄国军舰。我们借着风势飞速逃跑，而那艘双桅帆船却紧紧逼近，我们每前行两英尺，它就追上来三英尺。在船尾站着的那个人就是那个头发像海狮鬃毛的家伙，他正按住栏杆，压着帆，信心满满地笑着。昂加也在那里——我一下子就认出她了——但是大炮从海面上飞过来的时候，他就把她送到舱里去了。我刚才讲过，我们的船行驶两英尺，他们就追上来三英尺，直到它被浪一颠，我们才看见那绿色的舵——我们已经在俄国人炮弹的射程里了，我一边掌好舵轮，一边诅咒。因为我们都知道，他是故意要跑到我们前头，这样，他就能趁我们被逮住时跑掉。他们把我们的桅杆给炸飞了，我们就像受了伤的海鸥似的被扯进风里；但是他却一直往前驶去，驶出了水平线——他和昂加。
An Odyssey of the North: “The men by Yeddo Bay had met from the ends of the earth, and had neither gods nor homes, sailing under the flag of the Japanese.And with them I went to the rich beaches of Copper Island, where our salt-piles became high with skins.And in that silent sea we saw no man till we were ready to come away.Then, one day, the fog lifted on the edge of a heavy wind, and there jammed down upon us a schooner, with close in her wake the cloudy funnels of a Russian man-of-war.We fled away on the beam of the wind, with the schooner jamming still closer and plunging ahead three feet to our two.And upon her poop was the man with the mane of the sea lion, pressing the rails under with the canvas and laughing in his strength of life.And Unga was there,—I knew her on the moment,—but he sent her below when the cannons began to talk across the sea.As I say, with three feet to our two, till we saw the rudder lift green at every jump,—and I swinging on to the wheel and cursing, with my back to the Russian shot.For we knew he had it in mind to run before us, that he might get away while we were caught.And they knocked our masts out of us till we dragged into the wind like a wounded gull; but he went on over the edge of the sky-line,—he and Unga.

北方的奥德赛: “我们能怎么办呢？刚剥下的海豹皮就是证据。所以，他们把我们带到一个俄国港口，然后又带到一个人迹罕至的地方，在那里他们逼着我们在矿里挖盐。有的人死了，还有——还有一些人保住了命。”
An Odyssey of the North: “What could we?The fresh hides spoke for themselves.So they took us to a Russian port, and after that to a lone country, where they set us to work in the mines to dig salt.And some died, and—and some did not die.”

北方的奥德赛: 纳斯撩开他肩上的毯子，露出粗糙变形的皮肤，上面有明显的被鞭子抽打过的一道道伤痕。普林斯赶紧给他盖好，因为那情景让人看着真不是滋味。
An Odyssey of the North: Naass swept the blanket from his shoulders, disclosing the gnarled and twisted flesh, marked with the unmistakable striations of the knout.Prince hastily covered him, for it was not nice to look upon.

北方的奥德赛: “我们在那里过得很煎熬；有的时候，也有人往南边逃跑，但是每次都被抓回来。所以，等到我们这些来自江户湾的人在夜晚行动起来，抢了警卫的枪以后，我们就往北方逃去。那一带地域辽阔，有湿乎乎的平原，还有大片的树林。严寒的时节到来了，地上有很厚的雪，没有人认得路。我们在没有边际的树林里走了好几个月，疲惫不堪——那样的日子，我如今已经不记得了，因为那里几乎没有什么吃的东西，我们经常是躺着等死。不过，最终我们还是来到了寒冷的海边，但是只剩下三个人看到了大海。一个是来自江户的船长，这一带陆地的地形都在他脑子里，他还知道人们可以从冰面上的某个地方由一个大陆到另一个大陆去。他带着我们——我不知道路有这么长——最后只剩下我们两个人。等我们到了那个从冰上过海的地方，我们碰见五个陌生人，他们是当地人，他们有狗和皮子，而我们一贫如洗。我们在雪里跟他们打了起来，最后他们被干掉了，船长也死了，狗和皮子就都是我的了。然后，我就走上了那片冰面，冰面裂开了，我曾经一度在海上漂流，直到西面来的一阵大风把我吹到了岸上。那以后，我又走过了戈洛文湾、帕斯提里克，以及那个神父那里。然后便是往南，再往南，到了我第一次去过的那个暖洋洋的、满是阳光的地方。
An Odyssey of the North: “We were there a weary time; and sometimes men got away to the south, but they always came back.So, when we who hailed from Yeddo Bay rose in the night and took the guns from the guards, we went to the north.And the land was very large, with plains, soggy with water, and great forests.And the cold came, with much snow on the ground, and no man knew the way.Weary months we journeyed through the endless forest,—I do not remember, now, for there was little food and often we lay down to die.But at last we came to the cold sea, and but three were left to look upon it.One had shipped from Yeddo as captain, and he knew in his head the lay of the great lands, and of the place where men may cross from one to the other on the ice.And he led us,—I do not know, it was so long,—till there were but two.When we came to that place we found five of the strange people which live in that country, and they had dogs and skins, and we were very poor.We fought in the snow till they died, and the captain died, and the dogs and skins were mine.Then I crossed on the ice, which was broken, and once drifted till a gale from the west put me upon the shore.And after that, Golovin Bay, Pastilik, and the priest.Then south, south, to the warm sunlands where first I wandered.

北方的奥德赛: “但是，从海里已经捞不到多少东西了，出去捕海豹利小险大。船队也很散，船长和水手都不知道我要找的那个人的消息。所以我就离开了永不宁静的大海，在树林、房子和大山永远静止不动的陆地上穿梭。我走了很远，也学会了很多，甚至还学会了看书写字。我觉得这样也不错，因为我想，昂加肯定也学会了这些事情，也许哪一天，到那天——我们——不用说你们也懂的，到了那一天。
An Odyssey of the North: “But the sea was no longer fruitful, and those who went upon it after the seal went to little profit and great risk.The fleets scattered, and the captains and the men had no word of those I sought.So I turned away from the ocean which never rests, and went among the lands, where the trees, the houses, and the mountains sit always in one place and do not move.I journeyed far, and came to learn many things, even to the way of reading and writing from books.It was well I should do this, for it came upon me that Unga must know these things, and that some day, when the time was met—we—you understand, when the time was met.

北方的奥德赛: “所以我到处漂泊，像那些只能迎风起航却没有舵的小渔船一样。但是我的眼睛和耳朵时刻都在注意看，留心听。我经常和那些走过很多地方的人打交道，因为我知道他们只要见过我要找的那两个人，就肯定不会忘记。最后，我遇见一个刚从大山里出来的人，他有几块矿石，里面嵌着很多跟豆子差不多大的金沙。他听说过他们，并且见过他们，还认识他们。他说，他们很有钱，就住在他们从地里挖金子的那个地方。
An Odyssey of the North: “So I drifted, like those little fish which raise a sail to the wind, but cannot steer.But my eyes and my ears were open always, and went among men who traveled much, for I knew they had but to see those sought, to remember.At last there came a man, fresh from the mountains, with pieces of rock in which the free gold stood to the size of peas, and he had heard, he had met, he knew them.They were rich, he said, and lived in the place where they drew the gold from the ground.

北方的奥德赛: “那是个人迹罕至的地方，还非常远；但是我总算到了那个藏在群山间的宿营地，那里的人没日没夜地干活，根本看不到太阳。我从那些人的谈话中听出来，时机还不成熟。他已经离开了——他们已经离开了——去英国了，听说，他们是想找几个有钱人来开公司。我看见了他们住的房子，就像古代国家里的宫殿一样。夜晚，我从窗子爬了进去，想看看他是怎么对她的。我从一个房间走进另一个房间，我觉得国王和王后过的就是这样的日子，美妙极了。他们都说他对她像对王后一样，很多人都纳闷她是什么民族的人；因为她的血管里流着不一样的血，她跟阿卡屯的女人不一样，没有人知道她是什么人。对，她是位王后；但是我是酋长，还是酋长的儿子，我为她付出了难以估价的皮子、船和珠子。
An Odyssey of the North: “It was in a wild country, and very far away; but in time came to the camp, hidden between the mountains, where men worked night and day, out of the sight of the sun.Yet the time was not come. Listened to the talk of the people.He had gone away,—they had gone away,—to England, it was said, in the matter of bringing men with much money together to form companies.I saw the house they had lived in; more like a palace, such as one sees in the old countries.In the nighttime I crept in through a window that I might see in what manner he treated her.I went from room to room, and in such way thought kings and queens must live, it was all so very good.And they all said he treated her like a queen, and many marveled as to what breed of woman she was; for there was other blood in her veins, and she was different from the women of Akatan, and no one knew her for what she was.Ay, she was a queen; but I was a chief, and the son of a chief, and had paid for her an untold price of skin and boat and bead.

北方的奥德赛: “但是，何必要说这么多呢？我是一个水手，我知道船在海上航行的路线。我跟着他们去了英国，接着又去了别的国家。有的时候，我从人们嘴里听到关于他们的一些情况，有的时候，我还会从报纸上读到关于他们的消息；然而我没有一次能见到他们，因为他们有很多钱，所以走得很快，而我只是一个穷人。后来，他们也遇上麻烦了，有一天，他们的财产像一缕轻烟一样没了踪影。那个时候，报纸上全刊登着这件事情；但是之后就没有消息了，我知道他们肯定又返回那个从土地里可以挖出更多金子的地方了。“如今，他们既然没钱了，也就被世人抛弃了；我从一个宿营地游荡到另一个宿营地，甚至还到了北方的库特奈地区，并在那里打听到一点儿过时的消息。他们去过那里，但是已经离开了，有人说往这边走了，有人说往那边走了，还有人说他们去了育空河。就这样，我先往这边走，再往那边走，总是从一个地方到另一个地方，一直走到我对这个广阔无边的世界感到厌烦了似的。但是，我在库特奈地区曾经跟一个西北地区的土人一块赶路，那条路很长也很不好走，他忍受不了饥饿的痛苦，觉得还是死了最好。他曾顺着一条没人知道的路，翻过大山，到了育空河一带。那时，他知道自己大限将至，就给了我一张地图，还告诉了我一个秘密的地方，他对天发誓，说那里有很多金子。
An Odyssey of the North: “But why so many words?I was a sailorman, and knew the way of the ships on the seas.I followed to England, and then to other countries.Sometimes I heard of them by word of mouth, sometimes I read of them in the papers; yet never once could I come by them, for they had much money, and traveled fast, while I was a poor man.Then came trouble upon them, and their wealth slipped away, one day, like a curl of smoke.The papers were full of it at the time; but after that nothing was said, and I knew they had gone back where more gold could be got from the ground.“They had dropped out of the world, being now poor; and so wandered from camp to camp, even north to the Kootenay Country, where picked up the cold scent.They had come and gone, some said this way, and some that, and still others that they had gone to the Country of the Yukon.And I went this way, and I went that, ever journeying from place to place, till it seemed I must grow weary of the world which was so large.But in the Kootenay I traveled a bad trail, and a long trail, with a ‘breed’ of the Northwest, who saw fit to die when the famine pinched.He had been to the Yukon by an unknown way over the mountains, and when he knew his time was near gave me the map and the secret of a place where he swore by his gods there was much gold.

北方的奥德赛: “那以后，所有的人都向北方涌去。我是个穷光蛋，只好把自己卖给其他人赶狗。剩下的你们就知道了。我在道森遇上了他们两个。她没认出我来，因为那时我还年轻，而她的日子又过得那么富有，所以她也没有闲暇记着我这个为她付出那么多代价的人。
An Odyssey of the North: “After that all the world began to flock into the north.I was a poor man; I sold myself to be a driver of dogs.The rest you know. I met him and her in Dawson.She did not know me, for I was only a stripling, and her life had been large, so she had no time to remember the one who had paid for her an untold price.

北方的奥德赛: “可不是吗？你帮我提前逃脱了苦役。我想返回去，按照我自己的方式去办事；因为我已经等了很久，如今既然他已经在我手里了，我就不必急在一时了。我说过的，这件事我想用自己的方法去办；因为我回想了自己这一辈子，包括所有我看到的和经历过的事情，还想起了在俄罗斯海边漫无边际的树林里所经受的饥寒交迫。你们都知道，我领着他——他和昂加——往东走，很多人去那里，但是回来的并不多。我把他们带到受人诅咒的地方，那里遍地白骨和带不走的黄金。
An Odyssey of the North: “So?You bought me from my term of service.I went back to bring things about in my own way; for I had waited long, and now that had my hand upon him was in no hurry.As I say, I had it in mind to do my own way; for I read back in my life, through all I had seen and suffered, and remembered the cold and hunger of the endless forest by the Russian Seas.As you know, I led him into the east,—him and Unga,—into the east where many have gone and few returned.I led them to the spot where the bones and the curses of men lie with the gold which they may not have.

北方的奥德赛: “路很长，路上的雪都没人踩过。我们有很多狗，它们吃得也多；我们的雪橇不能把开春之前所需要的东西都带上。我们必须在河水融化之前返回。所以，我们就沿途藏了一些食物，这样雪橇的负担就轻一些，而回来的时候我们又不会被饿死。有三个人在麦克奎森住着，我们在他们附近搭建了一个藏食物的棚子，到了马育，我们又搭了一个，那个地方有十二个佩利人在狩猎宿营，他们是穿过南边的分水岭到那里的。在那之后，我们再往东边走，就看不到人了；只有安睡的河流、纹丝不动的树林和北方万籁俱寂的雪原。我说过，那条路很长，雪也没有人踩过。有的时候，我们劳累了一整天，也不过行进八到十英里路，到了晚上，我们睡得像死人一样沉。他们连做梦都不会想到我就是纳斯，阿卡屯的酋长，想要复仇的人。
An Odyssey of the North: “The way was long and the trail unpacked.Our dogs were many and ate much; nor could our sleds carry till the break of spring.We must come back before the river ran free.So here and there we cached grub, that our sleds might be lightened and there be no chance of famine on the back trip.At the McQuestion there were three men, and near them we built a cache, as also did we at the Mayo, where was a hunting-camp of a dozen Pellys which had crossed the divide from the south.After that, as we went on into the east, we saw no men; only the sleeping river, the moveless forest, and the White Silence of the North.As say, the way was long and the trail unpacked.Sometimes, in a day’s toil, we made no more than eight miles, or ten, and at night we slept like dead men.And never once did they dream that I was Naass, head man of Akatan, the righter of wrongs.

北方的奥德赛: “这个时候，我们搭的棚子比过去小了，到了晚上，我便轻而易举地沿着来时的路回去，把食物转移到别的地方，让人以为是黑獾偷走了食物。另外，还有那种容易掉进水里的地方，因为水流湍急，冰只结在表面，下面的那层很容易受河水冲刷。在这样一个地方，我赶的雪橇连狗一起掉下去了；这对于他和昂加来说是很不幸的事，但是之后再没有发生过这样的事。那架雪橇上有很多食物，狗也是最壮实的。但是因为身体强壮，他反而大笑起来，给剩下的狗很少的食物，后来我们就割断缰绳，把它们一个一个喂给它们的同伴。他说，这样的话，我们回去的时候负担就少了，我们可以沿途从这个棚子吃到那个棚子，就不需要狗跟雪橇了；这倒不假，因为我们的食物确实不多了，等到那个晚上，我们到了那个布满黄金和白骨、受人诅咒的地方，剩下的最后一条狗也死在挽具里了。
An Odyssey of the North: “We now made smaller caches, and in the nighttime it was a small matter to go back on the trail we had broken, and change them in such way that one might deem the wolverines the thieves.Again, there be places where there is a fall to the river, and the water is unruly, and the ice makes above and is eaten away beneath.In such a spot the sled I drove broke through, and the dogs; and to him and Unga it was ill luck, but no more.And there was much grub on that sled, and the dogs the strongest.But he laughed, for he was strong of life, and gave the dogs that were left little grub till we cut them from the harnesses, one by one, and fed them to their mates.We would go home light, he said, traveling and eating from cache to cache, with neither dogs nor sleds; which was true, for our grub was very short, and the last dog died in the traces the night we came to the gold and the bones and the curses of men.

北方的奥德赛: “要达到那个地方——地图上标得很好——在群山中间，我们得在一个冰封的分水岭的峭壁上凿出一些台阶。我们期望分水岭后面有一个山谷，但是没有山谷；取而代之的是皑皑白雪，像丰收的大平原一样伸展开来，我们的周围都是傲然耸立的山峰，它们纷纷把白色的峰尖挤进群星之中。在那片原本应当是山谷的奇怪的大平原中间，地面和积雪都往下沉，似乎一直沉到了地球的心脏里。假如我们没有当过水手的话，见到这样的情景，我们肯定会头晕目眩；但是，我们依然站在这让人眩晕的山边，想找一条到下边去的路。而且其中有一侧，并且只有这一侧的峭壁是像刮起暴风时的甲板一样渐渐倾斜的。我不知道为什么会是那样，但是它就是那样。他说：‘这是地狱的入口，我们到下面去吧。’然后我们便下去了。
An Odyssey of the North: “To reach that place,—and the map spoke true,—in the heart of the great mountains, we cut ice steps against the wall of a divide.One looked for a valley beyond, but there was no valley; the snow spread away, level as the great harvest plains, and here and there about us mighty mountains shoved their white heads among the stars.And midway on that strange plain which should have been a valley, the earth and the snow fell away, straight down toward the heart of the world.Had we not been sailormen our heads would have swung round with the sight; but we stood on the dizzy edge that we might see a way to get down.And on one side, and one side only, the wall had fallen away till it was like the slope of the decks in a topsail breeze.I do not know why this thing should be so, but it was so.‘It is the mouth of hell,’ he said; ‘let us go down.’And we went down.

北方的奥德赛: “山谷底部有一个小木屋，可能是过去有人从上面把木头丢下去，然后建造的。那是一栋非常老的木屋；因为不同时期到那里的人都孤孤单单地死在那个屋子里了，我们从地上的一些桦树皮上看见了他们临死前留下的文字和诅咒。有一个是得坏血病死的；还有一个是因为他的同伴抢走了他仅剩的一点儿食物和火药以后逃走了；第三个是被一只脸上有白斑的灰熊给弄死的；第四个想捕猎来充饥，但还是饿死了——还有其他的，情况都差不多。他们都不愿意离开那些金子，最终只能死在金子旁边了，只是各有各的死法。他们挖来的那些没用的金子铺在木屋的地板上，到处金光闪闪的，让人感觉就像在梦中一样。
An Odyssey of the North: “And on the bottom there was a cabin, built by some man, of logs which he had cast down from above.It was a very old cabin; for men had died there alone at different times, and on pieces of birch bark which were there we read their last words and their curses.One had died of scurvy; another’s partner had robbed him of his last grub and powder and stolen away; a third had been mauled by a bald-face grizzly; a fourth had hunted for game and starved,—and so it went, and they had been loath to leave the gold, and had died by the side of it in one way or another.And the worthless gold they had gathered yellowed the floor of the cabin like in a dream.

北方的奥德赛: “但是，被我带到这么远的那个人，他内心很平静，脑子也很清醒。他说：‘我们没有吃的了，我们只能看看这里的金子，搞清楚它从什么地方来的，究竟有多少。之后我们就必须赶紧离开，以免它跳进我们的眼睛，偷走了我们的控制力。这样的话，最终我们还能回来，多带点吃的，那么所有的金子就都属于我们了。’于是，我们观察了一下那个大矿脉，它就像人的静脉一样贯穿着矿壁；我们量了一下，又从上往下勾勒出它的轮廓，然后打下一个个木桩子，并且在树上刻下了字，作为归我们所有的标志。那个时候，因为没有食物，我们的膝盖都在打颤，肚子里非常难受，心脏也扑通扑通地就快跳到嗓子眼了，所以，我们最终还是爬上了那个陡峭的岩壁上，开始往回走了。
An Odyssey of the North: “But his soul was steady, and his head clear, this man I had led thus far.‘We have nothing to eat,’ he said, ‘and we will only look upon this gold, and see whence it comes and how much there be.Then we will go away quick, before it gets into our eyes and steals away our judgment.And in this way we may return in the end, with more grub, and possess it all.’ So we looked upon the great vein, which cut the wall of the pit as a true vein should; and we measured it, and traced it from above and below, and drove the stakes of the claims and blazed the trees in token of our rights.Then, our knees shaking with lack of food, and a sickness in our bellies, and our hearts chugging close to our mouths, we climbed the mighty wall for the last time and turned our faces to the back trip.

北方的奥德赛: “在最后一段路上，我们两个人搀着昂加走，我们总是摔倒，不过最终我们还是到了那个藏食物的棚子。看，根本没有食物。这事做得天衣无缝，他以为是被黑獾偷去了，他不断地咒骂那些黑獾跟他的神。但是昂加什么都不怕，她笑着把手放在他手里，而我不得不背过身子，努力控制自己的情绪。她说：‘我们就在火跟前歇息到早上吧，我们可以先把鹿皮鞋吃了，好增加点儿力气。’于是，我们就把鹿皮鞋的鞋筒割成一条一条的，煮了半夜，这样我们才能嚼烂了吞进肚子里。早上我们谈了谈我们的处境。到下一个棚子还有五天的行程；我们是走不到那里的。我们必须得找到野兽才行。
An Odyssey of the North: “The last stretch we dragged Unga between us, and we fell often, but in the end we made the cache.And lo, there was no grub.It was well done, for he thought it the wolverines, and damned them and his gods in the one breath.But Unga was brave, and smiled, and put her hand in his, till I turned away that I might hold myself.‘We will rest by the fire,’ she said, ‘till morning, and we will gather strength from our moccasins.’So we cut the tops of our moccasins in strips, and boiled them half of the night, that we might chew them and swallow them.And in the morning we talked of our chance.The next cache was five days’ journey; we could not make it.We must find game.

北方的奥德赛: ‘我们去捕猎吧。’他说。
An Odyssey of the North: ‘We will go forth and hunt,’ he said.

北方的奥德赛: 我说：‘好，我们捕猎去。’
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Yes,’ said I, ‘we will go forth and hunt.’

北方的奥德赛: “他命令昂加留在火堆旁，保存力气。然后我们就动身了，他去找驼鹿，我去找我转移了的食物棚。但是我只吃了一点儿，这样他们就看不出我的体力不弱。晚上，在返回露营地的路上，他摔倒了好多回。我也假装很虚弱，总是被雪鞋绊倒，好像每走一步都是最后一步似的。后来我们把鹿皮鞋吃了才有了点儿力气。
An Odyssey of the North: “And he ruled that Unga stay by the fire and save her strength.And we went forth, he in quest of the moose, and I to the cache I had changed.But I ate little, so they might not see in me much strength.And in the night he fell many times as he drew into camp.And I too made to suffer great weakness, stumbling over my snowshoes as though each step might be my last.And we gathered strength from our moccasins.

北方的奥德赛: “他是个很棒的人。他的精神一直支撑着他的身体到最后的时刻；除了为昂加之外，他始终没有放声哭过。第二天，我跟着他去捕猎，怕最后见不着他了。他经常躺下歇息。那天晚上，他快不行了；但是到了早上，他无力地咒骂了几句，又接着往前走。他好像一个喝多了酒的人，有很多回我都感觉他要不行了；但是他很坚强，有巨人一样的灵魂支撑着他的身体熬过那疲惫不堪的一天。他猎到了两只松鸡，但是他不愿意吃。他根本用不着火；它们能挽救他的性命；但是他想着昂加，所以他转身往我们的露营地去了。他走不动了，但是他用手和膝盖撑在雪里往前爬。我走到他面前，在他眼睛里看到了死亡的气息。尽管到了那个时候，只要吃了松鸡，还来得及。他扔掉了来复枪，像狗一样，用嘴叼着那两只松鸡。我在他身旁走着，身体挺得直直的。然后他歇息的时候看了看我，奇怪我为什么这么强壮。我能看出来，尽管他已经说不出话了；他嘴唇动了动，但没有发出声音。我说过，他是个很棒的人，我的心也有点儿软了；但是回想起过去的事情，我记起了自己在俄罗斯海边漫无边际的树林里经受了怎样的饥寒交迫。何况，昂加本来是我的，我为她付了皮子、船和珠子的高昂的价格。
An Odyssey of the North: “He was a great man.His soul lifted his body to the last; nor did he cry aloud, save for the sake of Unga.On the second day followed him, that I might not miss the end.And he lay down to rest often.That night he was near gone; but in the morning he swore weakly and went forth again.He was like a drunken man, and I looked many times for him to give up; but his was the strength of the strong, and his soul the soul of a giant, for he lifted his body through all the weary day.And he shot two ptarmigan, but would not eat them.He needed no fire; they meant life; but his thought was for Unga, and he turned toward camp.He no longer walked, but crawled on hand and knee through the snow.I came to him, and read death in his eyes.Even then it was not too late to eat of the ptarmigan.He cast away his rifle, and carried the birds in his mouth like a dog.I walked by his side, upright.And he looked at me during the moments he rested, and wondered that I was so strong.I could see it, though he no longer spoke; and when his lips moved, they moved without sound.As I say, he was a great man, and my heart spoke for softness; but I read back in my life, and remembered the cold and hunger of the endless forest by the Russian Seas.Besides, Unga was mine, and I had paid for her an untold price of skin and boat and bead.

北方的奥德赛: “就这样，我们穿过了白雪皑皑的树林，周围一片寂静，好像海上潮湿的雾一样重重地压在我们身上。过去的幻影弥漫在空中，笼罩在我们周围；我看到了阿卡屯黄色的沙滩，捕完鱼冲回家的皮舟，还有树林边上的房子。还有那两个自封为酋长的人，这两个立下各种规矩的人，一个是我的祖先，一个是嫁给我的昂加的祖先。不错，雅希－奴希也走在我旁边，他的头发上粘着潮湿的沙子，还有那根他摔倒时被折断的长矛依然在他手里。我知道是时候了，我看见了昂加眼里默然相许的目光。
An Odyssey of the North: “And in this manner we came through the white forest, with the silence heavy upon us like a damp sea mist.And the ghosts of the past were in the air and all about us; and I saw the yellow beach of Akatan, and the kayaks racing home from the fishing, and the houses on the rim of the forest.And the men who had made themselves chiefs were there, the lawgivers whose blood I bore, and whose blood I had wedded in Unga.Ay, and Yash-Noosh walked with me, the wet sand in his hair, and his war spear, broken as he fell upon it, still in his hand.And I knew the time was met, and saw in the eyes of Unga the promise.

北方的奥德赛: “我说过，我们就这样穿过树林，直到营火的烟味钻进我们的鼻子。于是我弯下腰，从他嘴里抢过了那两只松鸡。他侧过身子，休息了一会儿，他的眼中露出惊讶的神色，他身下的那只手慢慢往他屁股上的那把刀摸过去。但是我把他的刀拿走了，在他眼前笑了起来。直到那个时候，他还是不知道。于是，我就做出从黑瓶子里喝酒的样子，假装在雪地上摞起一堆高高的货物，把那天晚上我结婚时的情景重演了一遍。我什么都没说，但是他懂了。然而他并不害怕。他的嘴角露出一丝讥笑，透露着冷冷的愤怒，知道了这些，他好像又有了些力气。路并不远，但是雪很厚，他慢慢地拖着自己的身子。有一回，他躺了很长时间，我把他翻过来，看着他的眼睛。他有时候往前面看，有时候目光呆滞。等我松开他以后，他又挣扎着往前爬。就这样，我们到了火堆旁边。昂加马上走到他身边。他的嘴唇动了几下，没有声音；接着他指了指我，希望昂加能明白。然后他便躺在雪里，静静地躺了很长时间。如今他仍然在那里躺着。
An Odyssey of the North: “As I say, we came thus through the forest, till the smell of the camp smoke was in our nostrils.And I bent above him, and tore the ptarmigan from his teeth.He turned on his side and rested, the wonder mounting in his eyes, and the hand which was under slipping slow toward the knife at his hip.But I took it from him, smiling close in his face.Even then he did not understand.So I made to drink from black bottles, and to build high upon the snow a pile of goods, and to live again the things which happened on the night of my marriage.I spoke no word, but he understood.Yet was he unafraid.There was a sneer to his lips, and cold anger, and he gathered new strength with the knowledge.It was not far, but the snow was deep, and he dragged himself very slow.Once, he lay so long, I turned him over and gazed into his eyes.And sometimes he looked forth, and sometimes death.And when I loosed him he struggled on again.In this way we came to the fire.Unga was at his side on the instant.His lips moved, without sound; then he pointed at me, that Unga might understand.And after that he lay in the snow, very still, for a long while.Even now is he there in the snow.

北方的奥德赛: “我一直在做松鸡，没有说话。然后我跟她说话，说的是她很多年没有听过的家乡话。她直起身，就这样，由于惊讶，眼睛睁得很大，她问我是什么人，从什么地方学来的这种话。
An Odyssey of the North: “I said no word till I had cooked the ptarmigan.Then I spoke to her, in her own tongue, which she had not heard in many years.She straightened herself, so, and her eyes were wonder-wide, and she asked who I was, and where I had learned that speech.

北方的奥德赛: “我说：‘我是纳斯。’
An Odyssey of the North: “‘I am Naass,’ I said.

北方的奥德赛: ‘你？’她说，‘是你？’她爬到我面前好看个清楚。
An Odyssey of the North: ‘You?’ she said.‘You?’ And she crept close that she might look upon me.

北方的奥德赛: ‘是的，’我回答，‘我是纳斯，阿卡屯的酋长，我们整个家族最后一条血脉，就像你一样，你也是你们家族最后一条血脉。’
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Yes,’ I answered; ‘I am Naass, head man of Akatan, the last of the blood, as you are the last of the blood.’

北方的奥德赛: “她笑了。我用我见过的和做过的一切发誓，我再也不要听到那样的笑声。它让我心寒，在那万籁俱寂的雪野里，只有我一个人和死神，还有那个大笑的女人坐在那里。
An Odyssey of the North: “And she laughed.By all the things I have seen and the deeds I have done, may I never hear such a laugh again.It put the chill to my soul, sitting there in the White Silence, alone with death and this woman who laughed.

北方的奥德赛: ‘过来！’我说，因为我觉得她已经疯了，‘吃点儿东西，我们就走吧。从这里到阿卡屯还有很远的路呢。’
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Come!’ I said, for I thought she wandered.‘Eat of the food and let us be gone.It is a far fetch from here to Akatan.’

北方的奥德赛: “但是她把脸藏进他的黄头发里，一直笑，直笑到仿佛我们耳边的天就要掉下来了似的。我原本以为她见到我会欣喜若狂，会马上记起过去的事情；但是她用这样的方式，让我感觉很诧异。‘过来！’我使劲抓住她的手，大声喊道，‘路又远又黑。我们快点儿吧！”
An Odyssey of the North: “But she shoved her face in his yellow mane, and laughed till it seemed the heavens must fall about our ears.I had thought she would be overjoyed at the sight of me, and eager to go back to the memory of old times; but this seemed a strange form to take.‘Come!’ I cried, taking her strong by the hand.‘The way is long and dark.Let us hurry!’

北方的奥德赛: ‘去什么地方？’她不再奇怪地笑了，坐起来问我。
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Where?’ she asked, sitting up, and ceasing from her strange mirth.

北方的奥德赛: ‘去阿卡屯。’我答道，盼望着她一听见我的话，脸上会露出快乐的神情。但是她跟他一样，嘴角露出一丝讥笑，流露出冷冷的愤怒。
An Odyssey of the North: ‘To Akatan,’ I answered, intent on the light to grow on her face at the thought.But it became like his, with a sneer to the lips, and cold anger.

北方的奥德赛: ‘好啊，’她说，‘我们走吧，手牵着手，我和你，一起到阿卡屯去。我们去住那肮脏的茅屋，吃鱼和油，再生个孩子——让我们一辈子都为之骄傲的孩子。我们会忘记这个世界，会幸福，非常幸福。真是太棒了，棒极了。来吧！我们赶紧走。我们一起回阿卡屯去。’
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Yes,’ she said; ‘we will go, hand in hand, to Akatan, you and I.And we will live in the dirty huts, and eat of the fish and oil, and bring forth a spawn,—a spawn to be proud of all the days of our life.We will forget the world and be happy, very happy.It is good, most good.Come!Let us hurry.Let us go back to Akatan.’

北方的奥德赛: “她一边用手抚弄着他的黄头发，一边不怀好意地笑着。她的眼里没有默然相许的意思。
An Odyssey of the North: “And she ran her hand through his yellow hair, and smiled in a way which was not good.And there was no promise in her eyes.

北方的奥德赛: “我坐在那里一声不吭，弄不明白这个女人为什么这么奇怪。我记起了那天晚上他把她从我那里拽走的时候，她尖叫着撕扯着他的头发——如今，她却抚弄着它，不舍得放下。后来我还记起了我付出的代价和常年的等待；我牢牢抓住她，像他过去那样把她拽走。她也像那天晚上一样，倒退着，像一只母猫被人从小猫身边拽走那样挣扎着。等到我们到了火堆的另一面，和那个男人分开以后，我才松开了她，她坐下来听我说话。我给她讲了我所经历过的一切，我讲了我在陌生的海上和陌生的土地上所经历的事情；我讲了我怎样找得疲惫不堪，好多年忍饥挨饿，还有最初我的承诺。哎，我全跟她讲了，甚至包括那天我和那个男人所经历的一切，还有前些天的事情。我说话的时候，看到她眼中渐渐流露出蓦然相许的神色，像破晓时分的天空，又饱满，又丰富。我看见了她眼里流露出的同情、女性的柔情、爱意，和昂加的心和灵魂。于是，我又成了一个小伙子，因为这种神情就是当初昂加跑上沙滩，一边笑，一边跑进她母亲房子里去时露出的那种神情。严厉和不安不见了，饥饿和疲倦的等待也结束了。是时候了。我感觉到了她内心的呼唤，似乎是让我把头枕在她胸口，忘记所有的事情。她向我张开双臂，我朝她奔了过去。然后，突然之间，她的眼里迸发出了仇恨的火焰，她的手已经在我的腰部了。一刀、两刀，她捅了我两刀。
An Odyssey of the North: “I sat silent, and marveled at the strangeness of woman. I went back to the night when he dragged her from me, and she screamed and tore at his hair,—at his hair which now she played with and would not leave.Then I remembered the price and the long years of waiting; and gripped her close, and dragged her away as he had done.And she held back, even as on that night, and fought like a she-cat for its whelp.And when the fire was between us and the man, I loosed her, and she sat and listened.And I told her of all that lay between, of all that had happened me on strange seas, of all that I had done in strange lands; of my weary quest, and the hungry years, and the promise which had been mine from the first.Ay, I told all, even to what had passed that day between the man and me, and in the days yet young.And as spoke I saw the promise grow in her eyes, full and large like the break of dawn.And I read pity there, the tenderness of woman, the love, the heart and the soul of Unga.And I was a stripling again, for the look was the look of Unga as she ran up the beach, laughing, to the home of her mother.The stern unrest was gone, and the hunger, and the weary waiting.The time was met.I felt the call of her breast, and it seemed there I must pillow my head and forget.She opened her arms to me, and I came against her.Then, sudden, the hate flamed in her eye, her hand was at my hip.And once, twice, she passed the knife.

北方的奥德赛: ‘狗！’她冷笑着把我推到雪里。‘猪！’然后她便大笑起来，直到笑声打破了寂静的夜，她又回到她的死人身边。
An Odyssey of the North: ‘Dog!’ she sneered, as she flung me into the snow.‘Swine!’ And then she laughed till the silence cracked, and went back to her dead.

北方的奥德赛: 我说过，她捅了我一刀，然后捅了第两刀；但是她饿得没了力气，根本杀不了我。然而，我还想呆在那里，合上眼睛，和那两个人一起长眠。他们的生活和我的生活交织在一起，把我引上了很多未知的路。但是我身上还有一笔债，让我无法安息。
An Odyssey of the North: As I say, once she passed the knife, and twice; but she was weak with hunger, and it was not meant that I should die.Yet was minded to stay in that place, and to close my eyes in the last long sleep with those whose lives had crossed with mine and led my feet on unknown trails.But there lay a debt upon me which would not let me rest.

北方的奥德赛: “路很长，天冷得刺骨，只有一点儿食物。佩利人没找到驼鹿，抢光了我的棚子。那三个白人也一样；但是经过他们的木屋时，我看见他们骨瘦如柴，已经饿死在那里了。后来的事我就不记得了，直到我来到这里，发现了食物和火——很多火。”
An Odyssey of the North: “And the way was long, the cold bitter, and there was little grub.The Pellys had found no moose, and had robbed my cache.And so had the three white men; but they lay thin and dead in their cabin as passed.After that I do not remember, till I came here, and found food and fire,—much fire.”

北方的奥德赛: 他讲完以后，羡慕不已地将身子靠近火炉。有很长一段时间，好像油灯的影子也在墙上演着一幕幕悲剧。
An Odyssey of the North: As he finished, he crouched closely, even jealously, over the stove.For a long while the slush-lamp shadows played tragedies upon the wall.

北方的奥德赛: “但是昂加！”普林斯叫道，那一幕情景还深深印在他脑子里。
An Odyssey of the North: “But Unga!” cried Prince, the vision still strong upon him.

北方的奥德赛: “昂加？她不愿意吃松鸡。她躺在那里，双手搂着他的脖子，脸深深埋在他的黄头发里。我把火挪近了一点儿，好让她不受冻；但是她爬到了另一边。我又在那一边生了火；但是也没什么用，因为她怎么都不愿意吃东西。就这样，他们仍然躺在雪里。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Unga?She would not eat of the ptarmigan.She lay with her arms about his neck, her face deep in his yellow hair.I drew the fire close, that she might not feel the frost; but she crept to the other side.And I built a fire there; yet it was little good, for she would not eat.And in this manner they still lie up there in the snow.”

北方的奥德赛: “那你有什么打算呢？”马尔穆特·基德问。
An Odyssey of the North: “And you?” asked Malemute Kid.

北方的奥德赛: “我不知道；阿卡屯很小，我不想回去，生活在世界的边缘。但是活着有什么意义呢？我可以去找康士坦丁队长，他会给我戴上手铐和脚镣，有一天，他们会给我套上一根绳子，这样，我就可以安安稳稳地睡了。但是——这也不行；反正我也不知道。”
An Odyssey of the North: “I do not know; but Akatan is small, and I have little wish to go back and live on the edge of the world.Yet is there small use in life.I can go to Constantine, and he will put irons upon me, and one day they will tie a piece of rope, so, and I will sleep good.Yet—no; I do not know.”

北方的奥德赛: “但是，基德，”普林斯抗议道，“这可是谋杀呀！”
An Odyssey of the North: “But, Kid,” protested Prince, “this is murder!”

北方的奥德赛: “嘘！”马尔穆特·基德命令道，“有些事凭我们的智慧和公道标准是无法判断的。是对是错，我们也说不清楚，也不能由我们来判断。”
An Odyssey of the North: “Hush!” commanded Malemute Kid.“There be things greater than our wisdom, beyond our justice.The right and the wrong of this we cannot say, and it is not for us to judge.”

北方的奥德赛: 纳斯向火炉靠得越来越近了。四处一片寂静，每个人的眼睛里都涌现出一幅又一幅的画面。
An Odyssey of the North: Naass drew yet closer to the fire.There was a great silence, and in each man’s eyes many pictures came and went.
